reviews.review: A must if you are interested in Samurai. The exhibits are well presented and in fantastic shape. The tour they gave (included in the ticket) was very interesting and helpful. The opportunity to wear a samurai armour was also a great idea. Our kids loved it as well. More interactive than expected and despite the slightly dodgy neighbourhood a must for anyone interested in Samurai history and culture. arigato gozaimasu!

History. Small museum but enough knwoledge for us to know about samurai. Ticket is included English guided tour, wearing samurai suits for taking pictures, how to use sword, samurai show. Two hours is ok for this museum. I give it 5 stars.

Great little museum. We had trouble finding this museum but lovely locals helped us out and really glad they did. Excellent value for money with a free guide who explains all the history etc and then at the end you get a free demonstration from an actor and can have a go if you want.

Wonderful insight into a bygone era. What a find and a great recommendation from our Hotel concierge! But at over Yen 5,000 for two adults and a child it was not cheap. The guided tour was well worth the time to learn more about Jane samurai, and helped put some of the pieces of japanese history and cult ire that we'd picked up along the way. We even learned the difference between a samurai and a ninja!Do it!

Pricey for what you get. My husband wanted to visit this museum as he's interested in samurai. We had some trouble finding it (the map on the website is deceptively simple), and were a bit surprised at the expensive entry fee (¥1,800 per person). There aren't many exhibits, but there is a demonstration of how the samurai sword is used in attack and defense. The demonstration is probably the best part of the visit; the exhibits aren't extensive at all, and frankly a bit disappointing. Visit it if you don't mind paying that much to enter, but if you'd rather save the money, I think there are other museums that will be more worthwhile visiting in Tokyo.

Well worth a visit!. The Samurai Museum was an unexpectedly interesting and enjoyable experience. We had an excellent tour guide who was very knowledgeable and spoke excellent English. The museum was very well done with a lot of fascinating artifacts and displays, as well as a chance to try on some samurai gear.

Nathan. Well worth a visit. Excellent personal guide around the museum, all in English. Gives a real insight into the Samurai period and left us wanting to learn more. Great picture opportunity at the end free of charge where you can dress up as a Samurai and in a kimono. The owner gave my girlfriend a present at the end, which was a really nice touch. Highly recommended

For those who love Samurai. You will explore samurai world here :) and all samurai suit from long period of time which are original oneAll staff here speak English influently and they guide us all about samurai historyThere was samurai show available but need to check timing (probably two times a day)You can also try samurai suit and take photo for free! for lady there was kimono available

Nestled in the weird part of Shinjuku is this Diamond of a Museum. Found this museum as a happy coincidence while walking through Shinjuku. It really is a contrast located in the nightlife Host/Hostess bar area, however truly is an amazing place.The entrance fee is 1800 yen which may seem steep. But the staff provide an amazing tour, and during the day they have certain experiences like a swordsmanship display.The museum has a number of original armours on display from the Edo Period. For example Shibata family armour, Oda Nobunaga armour etc. They also have a number of weapons like Musashi Miyamoto's actual sword.The staff are amazingly friendly and very knowledgeable of the exhibits, the tour takes up to an hour but is very informative. They also have a store selling a number of different items including replica swords and also real sword starting from 3000USDIf you have any interest in Japanese Edo History I highly recommend visiting this museum!

Impressive collection. Even though a small museum, one could easily spend 2-3 hours in there. The collection is quite impressive & well displayed, it's enough to illustrate history of the fighting class, the samurai spirit. Go early when it's less busy, & you'll get better attention with the guide, museum opens at 10:30am.
Great place to look into history. Very educational! Guide is very friendly and kind and spoke good english. We had the chance to wear the samurai helmet. Great expirience!
Samurai museum. Samurai museum sell swords and related things. Sods are about $200 Australian . But the Museum has genuine armour worn by ancient war lords. There is a guided tour. It opens at 11 am

Don't miss it !. I did not expect much but was really fascinated and impressed from the first moment I entered: the team of the museum really tries to welcome everyone personally and invited anyone to join one of the guided tours, all in English. Small groups are guided to each display section where guides explain the use and the history of the different items, mostly samurai armour and weapons of the different time periods. They even allow guests to try replicas helmets and face masks and invite them to take photos. Amazing !Don't miss the live action martial arts show when a master swordsman and actor shows off his skill with a real Samurai sword.

Great place to learn a bit of Samurai history. Shinjuku is a place with a lot of great shopping and restaurants. Tucked in a little street is a small museum that tourists could take a break from all the hustle and bustle, and spend a couple of hours learning a bit of Samurai history. The place is not huge, but there are Samurai armours and weapons. The ticket price includes a guided tour and demonstration. There's also a chance for the visitor to try on a headless and take pictures with it. My daughter did just that and she said the headress was very heavy. It was an enjoyable learning experience.

Worth a visit. The location is a bit out of the way in a rather sleazy part of Shinjuku. However the museum is worth seeing with a guide to explain some of the history. Yet it is rather small and expensive for a short visit. I would have liked more historical data.

Great museum. We visited this as my husband was interested in Samurai history. It was a little expensive to enter, however the staff guided us through the museum explaining the exhibits and the history behind them. We were also able to try one the armour and this really made you appreciate both the weight but also the flexibility of them. Great range of examples and in excellent condition. The afternoon demonstration was good and demonstrated the art behind the movements. You can also have a go too. Well worth the visit.

Brilliant . Just finished the show and tour. Loved it, the demonstration at the start was good then we had a lovely guide show us around who spoke good English and seemed to know what he was talking about. Very informative plus we then got to try on different outfits and have pictures. Some people in their reviews moan about the price but you get what you pay for and I enjoyed it. Will recommend to friends. Cheers

Amazing look into the Samurai History!!. I read good reviews on Trip Advisor so I had to check it out. It was as awesome as mentioned! Amazing armor battle suits, great demo and through history with very knowledgable staff! Such a cool part of Japanese history!!! Hight recommend it if you have two hours! Top notch!
Best museum in Tokyo . Definitely worth paying a visit, great museum, with live demonstration of Samurai art with swords.Guided visit is included in ticket price!

What a great way to spend a couple of hours!!!. Visiting the Samurai Museum was one of the highlights of our visit to Tokyo.It is not vast but is well designed. The multilingual staff were delightful and provided our group of four with an educational tour. The armor are well curated and all displays beautifully lit. We were given the opportunity to dress up in traditional costumes - which provided us with great photo opportunities!!!We joined a larger group for a demonstration of samurai techniques by an experienced samurai actor - his serious demeanor quietened the crowd and we were all transported by his skillful performance. Small gift shop. Would not hesitate to recommend.

Excellent Museum, Informative and Fun. Visited the Samurai Museum on a Saturday morning, was a bit busy at the entrance as everyone was waiting for the guided tour. Highly recommend doing the guided tour. The cost is already included in the entry ticket. Our guided tour group was too big to start with, but the staff quickly separated us into two groups which was fantastic. Our guide was very knowledgable in the Samurai history and able to explain the history in plain and fun way. It was a very enjoyable experience and also got to wear traditional Japanese and Samurai costumes at the end of the tour. There are also Samurai performances in the afternoon which are definitely worth watching. Again, the cost is already included in the entry ticket. Suggest you go in the afternoon if possible to fit both in at the same time.

Excellent experience. Much more than we expected and well worth the price. The free guided tour was unexpected but made it so much more informative. He took as much time as we wanted and answered all our questions. Afterwards there was an unexpected and impressive sword play demonstration. Fascinating.

An enjoyable history lesson. We enjoyed visiting the samurai museum in Tokyo. It is small but well designed. We liked how well kept are the armor pieces and the kids loved the opportunity to wear samurai customs and take pictures with the swards at the end of the visit.The visit includes a tour guide which is a big plus. Our guide was very helpful in explaining the complex history of the samurai and was able to easily answer all of our questions and colours to the visit.Did you know that the inspiration for the Darth Vader costume came from one of the samurai leaders? Check it out when you go to the museum...it was impressive to see the original character.It was great, and my only criticism is that the place is small. With hundreds of years of samurai domination I wish they had a larger museum that celebrates their history.

Worth It. An excellent two hours wandering through the history of Samurai from the Edo Period. A personal guided tour for a small group of six, in very good english, finished with a photo op in Samurai armour and Kimono, and a 20-minute exhibition/display of Samurai sword fighting at the end. Easy walk from JR Shinjuku station.I now know that Samurai were not fond of Ninja.
Excellent attraction! . Well worth the price. Great for guides, lovely facility, and a great way to spend 1-2 hours. I'd definitely recommend!

Awesome experience. Get there at 2pm for a demonstration. Very friendly informative staff and lots of interesting artefacts. Wear socks as you'll be taking your shoes off. You can try on some of the samurai gear. Very memorable visit, highly recommended.

Worth the visit and the entrance fee. Really well put together little museum and the bonus is a free guided tour by very well informed young english speaking guides plus a display of samurai sword play. We enjoyed it.

Small but very interesting museum.. I was in Tokyo on a business trip and had a spare hour in the afternoon, so decided to visit Samurai Museum. We have a guided tour and learned a bit of the Samurai and Japanese history.
Excellent experience!. Excellent experience, very informative and interesting. Must see! Plus you get to wear samurai armor
Great museum. Surprisingly great museum with lots of interesting artefacts and stories. Excellent guides with opportunity to try on the costumes. Well worth the 1,800 yen price.

Interesting museum for everyone. We took our 3 boys (aged 13,13 and 10) to this museum and they really enjoyed hearing about the Samurai and trying on the helmets and watching the demonstration. Our guide had excellent English and explained the different armour and weapons very clearly. There are enough interactive elements to keep the kids interested. Definitely worth a visit, particularly when combined with a visit to the ninja trick house down the road.

Do not miss out on this. This place was exceptional. We paid thinking we would walk around and read the wall plaques but our entrance fee included a guide who was knowledgeable on the history behind each display piece. He spoke incredible english and even recommended us other places to enjoy while on our trip. Seriously do yourself a favour and enjoy the culture and history the Samurai Museum has to offer

Great experience!. Small exhibition of Samurai armors and swords. 4 times a day there is a samurai show very interesting. The guides are nice and giving you many information about Japanese history. The ticket is a bit expensive but it is a nice experience.

Cute and charming museum. We visited this museum when it had recently opened so it wasn't crowded, we ended up having a guide walking with us. We learnt the history around the different items such as swords, costumes and shields which was interesting. We ended up at this place by accident as it was on our route to another place, it was worthwhile a visit if you are looking to kill time. Not a place I would recommend to friends though. Another charming thing about this place is that at the end you can dress up as a Samurai or a Samurai princess and they will take pictures.

Don't miss this gem . Beautiful armour in a small but charming museum with antique bamboo and tatami mats. The curators/guides spoke excellent English and this was a very special cultural highlight of our time in Tokyo.

Nice museum for boys . The museum is small but interesting. They have original and replica samurai costumes. My boys love this place. We were accompanied by a tour guide during our time there. She spoke perfect English and very nice. We had chance to try some traditional costumes and took pictures. The location wasn't easy to spot coz it's small so make sure you don't miss it

Worth the hour visit. Awesome place to learn about Samurai.The man who took us around had a great knowledge and although we didn't ask any questions, people in out group did and they were all answered. Fantastic collection, worth seeing.

Fantastic. This museum was brilliant, with a superb collection of armour, both original and replica, in addition to weapons and information. Furthermore, there are many helpful and kind tour guides. There was also a superb training demonstration by a samurai, with both photo and a question and answer session. Really brilliant. Then, there multiple opportunities to dress up in Edo-period Japanese clothes and this was good fun. Finally, we had the huge honour of meeting the Chairman, a humble and kind individual. If you have an interest in Japanese culture, particularly the way of the samurai, then please visit this museum.

Only if interested in historical warfare. It's a great little museum tucked away in Shinjuku. It's a private museum. There is a lot of good information regarding the samurai history. Take the free guide tour provided with your ticket to truly understand the various eras of the samurai. Not suitable for kids - especially from a tour guide narrative.

Absolutely worth visiting!!!. We didnt expect much and were absolutely surprised what this little museum had in store.There was an English speaking tour guide who walked us through the museum in little groups. He could answer a lot of questions and explained everything in detail. This is already included in the ticket price.There was also a samurai demonstration by a man who showed how a samurai uses his sword. You can also ask him questions.If you know a lot about this topic already, it might not be that informative. But we learned a lot and think its absolutely worth visiting. A wonderful surprise.
Cool. Small, but very interesting with a kind staff and a good guided tour. Beautiful armors and swords...You can touch some of it. Reccomend.

Very interesting museum. A very interesting museum. The guided tour (included with the ticket) is extremely interesting. The collection is fabulous. A must for anyone interested in history.There are also 15 min swords demonstration but only in the afternoon - so be aware that if you want to see this, it is better to come in the afternoon. They are hourly starting at 14:00. We unfortunately missed this.

a small collection. This is a private museum hosting a collection from a private individual. One sees a few cases of nice 18th century samurai armor and katanas, many replicas. There is also a daily sword show, which i missed. I thought the guide was sympatico, helpful and knowledgeable. This however cannot make one overlook the fact that the visitor is overcharged: the entrance fee is Y1800 - you'd see 100-fold more at any national museum, for ~Y400.

Educational and fun!. Great Samurai demonstration followed by a guided tour of the museum. The show and tour was 1,800 yen per person (approx $18 US). The show was amazing and lasted about 10 minutes. Afterwards, the Samurai (portrayed by an actor) posed for pictures and answered questions from the audience, that was about 15 people. Make sure to check the show times before you show up if that is something that interests you, as they only run at certain times. The tour guides spoke english quite well and were very knowledgeable about the history of the samurai. The tour consists of viewing artifacts (swords, weapons, helmets and samurai armor) and discussion over their use and the historical relevance of the samurai during that period. We spent about 1.5 hours at the venue, including 15 min at the gift shop. The place was very clean, well maintained and nicely appointed. I definitely recommend this and will go again next time I am in Tokyo.

Great tour guides!. This place is great if you want to learn about Japanese culture, and as we had an English speaking tour guide we got to know a lot of very interesting information! It's a perfect activity to do on a rainy/cold day.

Learn about life of samurai and get to dress up like one. Nice small place in the middle of Shinjuku. You get a guide that tells you all about the life of the samurai, the swords, the battles and the history. Outfits are pretty cool, so much detailing in every bit.They also have 4 shows that start at 2 pm, 3 pm, 4 pm and I think 5 pm. You get to see the samurai art of fighting shown by a japanese guy who practices it for 7 years. If you bought the ticket and visited before the show you can reenter with the same ticket to watch the show.You also get to try on the samurai head wear and some kimono for a photo.The place is in the middle of the Tokyo's red light district, so don't be surprised to see some "interesting" women and men hanging around it. Yes, even in the middle of the day. It is very entertaining, so don't rush to leave the area.;)

Out with friends. This is a small museum but our guide was very informative so it made the experience worth while. There is a demonstration at the end that is a little tedious but entertaining at first. I was a bit disappointed to find that samurai used guns and had sex with apprentices. Not quite how Hollywood depicts them!

Edo Period Education and Culture - Must do!. We stayed at Shinjuku Gracery and the museum was just around the corner. It is small but jam packed of history and culture with some original pieces all throughout the tour. It is a very traditional building with tatami rooms. Very special and fascinating. You even get to dress up - totally cool!!
I saw the sumo tournament here!. great seats, good food, great show! it was cool to see the rituals and traditions of the sumo wrestlers.

Cool. Period.. Just went there to waste time and ended up liking the damn place, they explain throughly everything that happened in each period of japan's history. At the end you meet a movie star that learned the samurai skills for 9 years

Informative and fun Museum for the whole family. We, 4 adults and 1 5-year old boy, visited this museum in late May. The museum wasn't busy and we waited just a few minutes for one of the English speaking guides. Our guide was not only knowledgeable regarding the costumes on display and their history, but he was also fun. We all enjoyed our tour and returned for the Samurai Sword presentation later in the afternoon.

Really interesting and entertaining. As with many people who visit Japan, I've enjoyed films, anime and games based around samurais so I was keen to visit this museum.Not only was it a chance to see some beautiful armour (the craft is incredible) but it was very educational. Due to the Samurai's influence and important in Japanese history you will learn about the history of Japan without being overwhelmed with information. What I really liked is that rather than focusing on what popular culture thinks of, samurai yielding katanas, the museum guide talked about the use of bows and guns.There was a demonstration of swordsmanship that was very well done plus there's a few opportunities to get involved. I tried on a replica helmet (still a handmade outfit) and got my photo which was fun!It is only a short visit, maybe an hour or so, which means that if you're in the area it is definitely worth fitting in. The shop was decent too.

Very worthwhile . My teenage son, teenage daughter and myself were going to go to the sword museum, but the poor reviews of the sword museum led us here instead. The samurai museum was totally worth seeing. Good English speaking guides were available immediately and took us through the two level exhibition. The information given was interesting as was some of the history. Previous Japanese history is not required, however, on reflection, I wish I knew something before going. I think I would have gotten more from the museum. There was a live demonstration as well as an multiple photo opportunities. The samurai armour sets are amazing to see. Lots of variety and colour. They are in extremely good condition. We were probably there for 60-70 minutes. 50-60 mins is probably the right kind of duration for most people I suspect. Worth seeing

Fantastic . Definitely worth a visit. Very friendly staff and interesting tour. So glad we went. The gentleman in the gift store was very nice and funny. I purchased a fantastic samurai sword umbrella !!

A MUST do in Tokyo!!. A relatively new museum, the staff guide the visitors through the hallways and rooms, explaining the history behind the different influential samurai, and offering insight to any questions guests may have. The physical demonstration was fantastic, and we got to ask the sword-wielder questions afterwards. Very Fun!

A Hidden Gem. Located in the back streets of Kobuchiko and can be difficult to find. Small place but very interesting collection of genuine artifacts from 1600's onwards. You get a small group or individual guided tour for a very reasonable fee. The tour guides are friendly, knowledgeable and speak very good english. They have a Samurai weapons demonstration several times daily.

Great collection of armor and interesting guided tour. This is an interesting little museum and worth a visit if you want to learn about the Samurai. They have great staff who speak a fair amount of English and enthusiastically describe the Samurai and armor. The tour is included in the price and worth the additional time as they provide a lot more information than you would pick up just going through on your own.

Small. but interesting nonetheless. Came here on a Thursday afternoon and it was quiet. The exhibition space is small, but whats on display is truly interesting. The swordsman performance is also very interesting, especially since there's a question and answers afterwards. The small gift shop is also fun to peruse. Recommended if you're going to be in the Shinjuku area.

Excellent museum, a must see. The museum was a short walk from my hotel so I figured give it a shot. I was not disappointed. It is a small museum but the guided tour makes it great. Our guide was knowledgeable, friendly and answered every question from the group. You can try on some of the gear at the end of the tour for photos. Try to time your visit for when they do the shows, I think 1 or 2 PM is the first show.

Shinjuku. We were exploring The streets of Shinjuku when we stumbled onto the museum. We had a great time discovering the samurai history. You will need take your shoes off when you go upstairs. You can also try on samurai and kimono clothing. The cost was 1800 yen each.
one of a kind. This is easy to access and takes just about 20 minutes to visit it all, but there is actual option to take picture in Samurai "costume".

Amazing collection, good tour guide. Impressive collection of Samurai costumes, swords and helmets! They assign an English speaking guide for each visiting group of around 6-8 people, and they are very knowledgeable and friendly. Visitors can try on the different costumes and pose for photos as souvenir too! We enjoyed the visit a lot! (The photos shown are not fully justifying how amazing the collections are.)

Pretty Cool . The Samurai Museum is worth a visit. The displays are very good and the tour guides are very friendly and speak good English. This is something that should be checked out. An interesting insight into the ancient world of the Samurai in Japan. There is also a small show from 2pm displaying the sword skills of a samurai.

Super interesting. The museum is tucked away in the popular red Light district of Tokyo - Kabuchiko. We just happened to walk by it and thought about doing a quick 15 min walk through. We ended up spending 2 hours there.The collections have been carefully collected and compiled. The staff is super knowledgeable and friendly. The walk through is fantastic..the best 800 yen you'll spend.If you walk in around 2 pm you'll get a chance to sit through a 30 min samurai show. It's absolutely brilliant. The best past is that you can touch and wear some of the pieces! And get to participate with the actor who plays the samurai!

Great insight into the history from a descendent of a samurai!. This private collection is an impressive and insightful peek into the long and rich culture and history of feudal Japan. The guide speaks fluent English and does continuous research on every item in the collection. The owner has spent several years privately collecting these weapons and armor, and each item has a significant feeling of history and filial lineage. This museum is a must-go if you have ever enjoyed a samurai movie or one set in the feudal eras of Japan.
It is feeling as it is a Japanese warrior. Samurai of Japan , in my country it is said that the very brave warrior .Its way of life and the idea is that all of the world's people should know more .

Brief but excellent. Was quite a small display, but of excellent quality. Some of the artifacts on display were very old displayed well. The people at the museum were very friendly and happy to walk us through the exhibits separately. We had a real samurai display and an opportunity after for a picture with him. This would be great for a family with small children. Nice and cool with air con too if you want to escape the midday heat.

You NEED a photo from here!. The mixed reviews of this place left me a little sceptical.... However .... It was kinda awesome!!!Our Guide was very friendly, funny and knowledgeable. The suits of armour and swords were beautiful and each was discussed so we understood them and how they were used. We also had two opportunities to try in some replica gear and see what it would be like to wear in battle... I can see some people thinking this is cheesy but we thought it was hilarious and had such a great time!There was also a demonstration which was interesting, a guy doing some stylised flow with a katana, a touch strange but again we thought it was excellent!Had a great time here overall and would definitely recommend it! Go with an open mind and have some fun!!

Very interesting with English speaking guide. After getting my ticket I was escorted around the whole museum by an English speaking guide. They had outfits (samuri for men and gowns for women) that you could wear and they took your picture (with your own camera). They also had a demonstration at the end that was interesting as well.

Small but interesting. My 14 yo son loved this museum. It will appeal to you if you have an interest in the different types and styles of samurai swords, armor and weapons, but not really much else. There is a short sword demonstration as well.
Just small private collection. Just a private collection. Not really traditional Samurai. Just a business to make money. I was looking for sometimes really especial about Samurais.
An educational tour of Japanese history. Definitely worth going to. The guides are excellent and it's an educational experience for anyone. The entry fee was great value for money.

For those interested in Samurai and Japanese history. This is a cool museum. They have a lot of beautiful pieces of Samurai armour on display along with Katanas and other less well known Samurai weapons. The tour guide was very friendly and knowledgeable about Samurai history and was very helpful in answering our questions. The highlight for me was being able to see the original Katana belonging to the Great Miyamoto Musashi. After the guided tour we got a watch a 10/15 min performance with an actor using a Katana along with a Q&A session and to top it off, you can take pictures whilst wearing Samurai armour. This was a fun tour which I highly recommend.

Samurais in Samurai museum. Tour was pleasant with nice gude who spoke very good english. There was possible to get good conversation of the topic as well. So the gudance was not just any well trained book text. Items were in good shape and in good order. Some items we were actually able and allowed to touch. Other items were just replicas, eg. some of the swords and armors. It was also fully allowed to take photos.Also the guide will take some photos of you after you have dressed like samurai. They have many costumes there to borrow. Nice feature to make otherwise hard topic much funnier.There was nice little souvenir shop where you could have get a real japanese sword as well. Don't know what they ment with it. At the shop they seemed to have only cheap replicas. Good addition was that you could send for eg. sword to home by mail from the shop and the staff will aid you thru it.I would have been more than satisfied to the standard tour. Anyway there was additional show part. I call it Hollywood part. There were some actor who showed some samurai postures and techniques. Not sure how real or where hes learned them, and honestly it felt little bit like made for dumb tourists. Anyway it was amusing.
Fun and educational. Highly interesting, super friendly staff and a lot of hands on where other museums are only displays. Thank you

Guided tour included to enhance your experience . Upon arrive, I thought it was a little expensive to be paying 1800yen for a tour that could possibly take 20-30 mins. My opinion changed when they provided a guide to show and provide history of the artefacts. Another plus is you get to take photos in samurai armor while holding a katana. I left feeling more curious and interested in Japanese history. Enjoy!

Definitely worth a visit. They had some cool pieces to view and an energetic and knowledgeable staff that were excited to take you from room to room and tell you the history of the items. My wife and I were also able to view a samurai demonstration and try on some outfits they had available. They also have a nice little gift shop that includes swords, if you're interested in shipping one back home. Worth a visit if you're in the area.

So fun!. Great small (1-2 hour) museum. Definitely touristy, but they have a nice collection of original & replica samurai armour, swords, & artifacts, and the staff gave excellent guided English language tour. Nice . Come by 5pm to catch a martial arts demonstration - cool, intense guy gives a demo of the samurai sword forms & a sort of mock one-man battle (like shadowboxing, but with a katana), and answers questions. They'll even take a fun picture of you in samurai gear at the end. The staff went out of their way to make us feel welcome & answer all our questions, even giving restaurant recommendations in the area. Would highly recommend!

Good for tourists. We enjoyed the short tour conducted by the guide. The intricately-made samurai armour are interesting especially when we compare the armour to those we have seen in other parts of the world.There was a specially humourous set of 3 where the tallest helmet was actually worn by the shortest shogun.My husband and I also dressed up as lord and lady in elaborate armour and kimono. That was fun to do. Gave us a good laugh.Too bad we didn't have time to watch the sword fighting demo. Had to fly home :(

Definitely recommend . This place was really cool I believe it was about 2000¥ and you get a guided tour a sword technique demonstration that lasted about 20 minutes and to dress up like a samurai and take pictures. Was really fun and neat to see all the different variations of the samurai. Definitely recommend

Informational short tour. This place with an 1800 yen entrance fee was worth the time. A group of friends and I came in and were accommodated with an English speaking tour guide that was patient with out questions and spoke clearly. The museum was small dimly lit but had a good atmosphere. Pictures were allowed but anything not on display was not well lit. The tour was great for Japanese history about samurai and at 1600 had a demonstration of ceremonial sword play which was a lot of fun to watch and he even let us hold the swords. Neat little gift shop worth the time.

Good if you want to kill some time. I think this visit was let down by the tour guide who I felt was 'winging it' during the whole tour. I didn't feel that her depth of knowledge about the Samurai period was good enough for her to be working as a tour guide. The entrance fee was also a lot given the size of the museum and poor quality of the tour. If you want a discounted entry price, look for a museum brochure at your hotel tourist desk.

Small but good. A small, private collection of original samurai armors and weapons. The objects are beautiful in themselves, and the English speaking guides (included in the ticket price) do a good job at telling their stories and putting them into the context of the fascinating history of the samurais. This makes it worth the admission fee, which may otherwise seem a bit steep for the size of the exhibition. Also included in the price, if you come in the afternoon, is a show of samurai fighting styles. If you miss this (as I did), you can come back another day on the same ticket. Recommended for spending an hour or two, for example to dodge a rainshower :-)

Marvelous Gem delivered a Wonderful Experience. The museum was small, but packed with Gems.Ultimately, it was our Guide and the Sword master show that made it a great experience.Our Guide was excited to learn we were from New York, and he bonded with us and gave us a spectacular tour, with great depth of knowledge of Japanese history !!We were worried it was very expensive, but the experience was PRICELESS.Our son got to try on a Samurai Helmet and were held a 400 year old musket.Sometimes great gifts come in small packages...Try this one

We came, we saw, we loved it. Got here at 10:30am and paid the entry fee...were immediately met by a guide (english speaking) who took us through the whole place. We got to dress up in the warrior armour and the kimonos...no extra charge and added greatly to the experience. Was awesome, definitely come here when in tokyo
Very Interesting. Got a guided tour and you can come back later in the day for other shows (its included in the ticket)

Save your Money ... Little to see and experience . We had high expectations of the Museum after reading reviews. Visited today , possibly 10 of so samurai uniforms and about 30 samurai swords to see.The experience starts when you go upstairs , take off your shoes and then go into a small room for a display of a person dressed up as a samurai going through some moves with a sword . After 2 mins it's enough . After 10 mins come on.. It then goes in again for another 5 mins. We walked out ... Boring to say the least.. Save your money .. It's really a huge yawn fest ...

Not the movie version. A compact, interesting and informative exposition of the Samurai era of Japanese history. Well guided with many interesting exhibits including a demonstration of the various ritual sword strokes of these warriors.

Simply Mesmerising Interactive Experience . I have been adoring samurai's all my life and when I got to experience and see this life of the samurai in this museum I was truly excited . The samurai have an iconic symbol of power, courage and masculinity over hundreds of years of Japanese history . I can truly feel the souls of the samurai in this museum . I truly recommend for those want see the culture of Japanese warfare to visit and experience this museum in shinjuku . The ticket is about 1,500 yen and for its worth the money spend . The ground floor has the souvenir shop and exhibits and the first floor has more exhibits and they different rooms with traditional tatami mats and paper screens with beautiful ambience in lighting . They also have performance and you can be part of the performance as well . I certainly took the opportunity to do it.Just check out my picture you will like it .

Small but fun museum. The museum was small, like only two floors in a regular building. But with the price you pay, you get a guided tour and a samurai show (15 min one person show). Best yet, you get to dress up as samurai, general or foot soldier. Girls, the Japanese pricess. We spent over one hour in this museum and kids enjoyed it.

Interactive Samurai Museum - over delivered 👍. We loved this fantastic experience at this museum. Our guide, Daiki gave us some extra info as we asked for it. We got extra information about not just history, but actual Japanese lifestyle. We could try on a replica, see a sword show, where my husband actively participated, touched some real relics. Could this be better? Ah photo-shooting! We got some daily samurai family clothes to try on and took some pictures. In the end you can buy your own katana (samurai sword) and get it delivered to your home. So no stress at the customs. Pretty cool! This is a private collection. Thanks for the owner making this place open for visitors! Really appreciated!
Cool place . It's a small museum but some cool stuff inside. I especially like Miyamoto Musashi's katana plus some other real ancient katanas. Very friendly staff and good guide accompany

Nice place to visit. Nice place smack in shinjuku. A good place to visit if you're not interested in other stuff around the area. Staff's are friendly, place is cool with all the artifacts and affordable.

LOVED it!. Just got back from our visit at the samurai museum, and we absolutely loved it. Our guide was super knowledgeable, and taught us a lot about the samurais and their era. Maybe you have to be especially interested in samurais and japanese history to enjoy, but we are, and it was amazing!

Two thumbs up!. I was skeptical from the outside but once we went in I enjoyed ever minute. Its not very big, just a few rooms with artifacts and memorabilia on display. You can walk around on your own or with one of the free casual info tours. The owner was on site giving one of the tours as well as a hand-full of english speaking guides. There was also a great Samurai demonstration with Q&A at the end.

Really worth visiting. Went there with my girlfriend on a raily weekday around mid-day. We got an English-speking guide who guided us and 4 more people. He spoke good English and explained the history of samurais with a great knowledge and a nice sense of humor. When I and the rest asked some specific questions he gave the answer immediatelly and just like that.They also had a presentation of using the samurai sword. It was given by a man who seem to been a tv- and movie actor. This guy knew how to use the sword. The presentations were at leat at 2pm, 3pm and 4pm (maybe later as well) but if you go there earlier like we did, you can come back for the presentation. There is a nice sushi place about 100-150 meters from the museum (can't remember its name) so we grabbed a bite and went back.If you have even the slightest interest in Japan history, you need to take a visit.+ you can test to wear those samurai armors yourself.

Very disapponting. Our expectations were very high, and they were not met. The place was very disorganised: we were taken to a show on the second floor in a rush, then left on our own in the middle of a room. Once we had a guide, he did not seem to know much about samurais and appeared in a hurry. His only objective was to have us taking pictures and share them on Instagram. There was no general introduction and historical descriptions whatsoever. The show only lasted 5 minutes, then the "samurai" took two tourists in the room to teach them some sword tricks while the others had to watch and do nothing: this was extremely boring. Plus it is the most expensive museum we visited in Tokyo.... It is not worth it...

Check this place out!. Was well worth the entrance fee. Has a collection of original armor as well as reproductions. English speaking guides are very knowledgeable on the subject. Lots of photo oppurtunities.

Really spectacular. I have always loved the Japanese Samurai and this place was great. We had a tour guide who spoke english and went through its history and answered any questions. The display was unique with some good histoy of japanese Samurai. The sword display was awesome and well worth the administration price

Lovely museum, full of history. We visited during our stay in Tokyo. We were surprised by a tour carried out by the owner museum who explained the details of the original artifacts kept here. We were also in time for a samurai demonstration which was informative. There was the opportunity to dress up for photos. The staff were very attentive and happy to answer any questions. We had a fantastic time and learnt so much about the samurai culture. Would definitely recommend this museum!
A bit pricey. A bit pricey. About $25 aid for entry and viewing of about 3 rooms. You pay really just for trying on the samurai costumes and taking photos.

Interesting with the Tour. This is a small but interesting museum. Some of the exhibits are original and others are replicas. I'm not sure if this was a standard practice, but someone working there gave me an English tour that was interesting and informative. The demonstration was interesting as well.
Touristy. The place was very touristy and limited in scope. With the raving reviews my expectations were a bit higher. Samurai demonstration was interesting but very unstructured.

Worth the expense.. We took our 3 boys to this museum and after the initial shock of the cost (60,000 yen) I discovered that we would have an english speaking guide. She was very nice and knowledgeable. Her english wasn't the best but it was FAR better than my Japanese. The children really enjoyed seeing the amour and had even more fun playing with the free swords the gift shop provided. In hindsight, I wish they'd gifted the swords after the tour but I can't really complain about free stuff. Towards the end of the tour we were allowed to try on helmets and various other robes as well as take photos- at no additional charge, which was cool. Overall, I found it to be fun and educational.

samurai treat, NO it can be sweet!. This place was amazing 300- 800 year old artefacts some you could touch! the tour guide was great it can speak a little Japanese but he could handle english like a A-Grade Baller! If you're in Shinjuku this is a must!

Excellent 1.5 hour spent. Small but personal tours. The guide was very knowledgable and answered several questions. The tours guides spoke English. Very informative tour which included a samurai sword and stance demonstration. There are some interactive displays: my son tried on a replica mask and helm. I was able to were a ceremonial kimono.

Best Museum We Visited. We got discount vouchers from our hotel. The museum is not where you'd expect to find the most traditional culture, in the red light district of Shinjuku. But we're glad we went! Our English guide was really knowledgable and took us around the whole museum as part of the entry price. We got to try on some replica armour and then she let us try on some kimonos and took pictures for us. It's a bargain for what you get. I'm not big into history and didn't really know anything about samurai past Tom Cruise but I felt like I learned something and was not bored.One of the best things to do in Shinjuku, especially if getting drunk isn't really your thing!

worth visiting. Although the museum is small, it is very interesting and well organized. They had volunteers who escort people around and explain all the different exhibit areas and answer questions. So glad we decided to go! It was not crowded when we went and was easy for us to get to, since we stayed near Shinjuku (it is north of the train station).

Fair price for a fun afternoon!. Really fun hour spent here. I really liked this museum as it is clear, concise and to the point, not flooded with textual information that will bore you. Initially I thought the entry price of ¥1800 was quite expensive but when we entered we were given a free personal tour, a chance to watch a samurai show which was great and the opportunity to try on traditional Japanese garments. All of which was worth the total entry price. At the end you can also buy a lot of souvenirs in the shop which is moderately priced. They can even send home samurai swords back to your home address for you if your country allows it!

Very good value for money. It has been our only such museum we have seen in Japan, and it was totally worth it:- very friendly staff, with deep knowledge of samurai history and Japan history, and with very good English skills.- live performance by an actor (several times per day, once per hour) showing the art of sword handling. Then they invited everyone to try some basic moved and to have their own pictures.- cool shop for souvenirs (some could be delivered at least to your hotel, if not also home abroad).I would recommend only some guidance signs on the nearby streets, as Google maps may not give the most accurate results and you may miss the location (quite a funky neighborhood).

Small, $18 and Worth Every Penny\. For roughly a 30 minute experience, you spend $18. That seems a bit crazy, initially, But, then you realize:1. You’re getting a guided and personal tour.2. The collection is hundred of years old and was procured by 1 person, the owner.3. You get to try things on and get a picture in a kimono or samurai outfit.All of a sudden $18 doesn’t seem too bad.

A Must See Museum. This small museum is a must see if in Shinjuku. It's small but not a single exhibit is a waste of time. The first floor features authentic samurai armor and after seeing these you move on to the second floor for a complete history of the samurai period. Such a fun experience.

A little difficult to find but worth it!. This is a great little museum. Every visitor seems to get a highly personalized tour around by the enthusiastic staff. We learned a lot. When we asked upon leaving how best to get tomthe metro, the Manager walked us there (several blocks) himself and gave us some interesting local color. Try to fit this in to your Tokyo sightseeing!

Okay on a rainy day. I felt that this museum was over priced and not a good value. It was one of the most costly museums and the smallest. I think you can get as much from the other historical museums in Tokyo (ex. Edo-Tokyo Museum) where there are some interactive experiences for the kids.We went because it was close to our hotel but I would not go again. We were in and out within 20 minutes.

Extremely worth it. A tour with explenation trough the museum a small show of a samurai and the possibility to dress up a bit as geisha/samurai makes this place extremely worth it for this small price.
Fantastic. Great presentation and great tour guide. Very friendly and welcoming staff.Recommended for anyone visiting Tokyo!!

A gem in Kabukicho. We purchased the tickets right at the museum. There was no line, and a tour guide was right there ready to show us around. The museum is small; there were probably 25 other visitors when we were there and it didn't feel too crowded. I would definitely recommend timing your visit according to their demonstration times which is posted on their website (English version available). A well-trained actor showcased samurai movements; the demonstration was very dignified and appreciated by our family.

Not really into Samurai but still very good!. Went here as a couple and enjoyed looking around the samurai museum, when we arrived they offered a guided tour in a small group which was really good including Tom Cruise Last Samurai joke (haha!)They allowed you to try on and take photos and genuinely seemed to enjoy working in the museum. They knew a lot about the features of the museum and it was very informative and not at all boring in any points I think helped by the fact the museum is not too large but a good size, a great experience and one I recommend.

Great for family with children . Most do list. I didnt think a museum was what we were going to on a holiday but our daughter 10 years Love this place. You can also try the costumes which give you good memory.

Excellent museum. I was really impressed with the Samurai Museum.Great displays and someone comes around and explains all the displays in interesting details.Worth staying for the Samurai show in the afternoons.Top class museum.Located right next to Kabukicho

Cool visit, instructif. Wanna learn about samurai ? This is the place to be. Great display of samurai armours, helmets, swords. Top floor you have a guide that tells and explains history, in english. There is also a demonstration of sword manipulation.

Great experience and english guide. This is a small but very nice museum close to the Shinjuku station. All staff members speak english and they guide you through the rooms describing the items and the Samurai history.Make sure to plan your visit when there is a Samurai demonstation where you can be the lucky one to try out some techniques.Highly recommended specially when you are traveling with kids.

Very informative!. As a personal collection of one man, the array of artifacts and information is staggering. The museum is quiet and small, however, each item is accompanied by an informative plaque and if you have the luck to get a personal guide to take you through you can learn much more and even try on some of the replica items. There is a small show where an enthusiastic staff member will run through the moves of the samurai with audience participation (though you do have to put you hand up!) There is a well-stocked gift store with many interesting and well-priced items.

Oh Dear! Consider Entrance As A Donation. Seriously, we should know better. Tourist area, tourist trap. At least the museum provides some lovely young people with employment. They ever so politley take your money.You will see a few genuine items of interest and quite a few reproductions of samurai objects. You have a 15 minute show (sword use display-dramatic) by a very nice young man and a tour of the items on display. I am not sure I would pay that kind of money $27 AU approx to see a similar display or that one again. If left to do the tour yourself, you could be in and out in 20 minutes.The museum knows that tourists like to play dress up, so you may find value in that.Not recommended.

Nice Tour for the Family. In the middle of the Shinjuku (Kubuki cho Red Light District area) is a relatively small private samuari collection.What I liked about this museum is that it is fully narrated by tour guides. The guides explain each of the authentic pieces in detail and you get much insight in what you are viewing.The tour takes only about an hour and ends with a fun free photo shoot (with your own camera) with samarai and kimono custumes.A fun interesting thing to do with your family in the middle of the red light district.

Lovely people, fascinating museum! . We Really enjoyed our visit here!! The staff were so friendly on arrival and offered to do a tour for us which was very interesting! We then watched a Samaria performance which was different and interesting to see! Finally we got to dress in Samaria clothing and get some pics which was very fun! Would definitely recommend if you're in the area!

Must See. A must see for those interested in knowing more about Samurai culture. Many exhibits and we went when there was a live demonstration on. It was great and worth it to see the actual explanation by a real Samurai

Worth It!. If you're like me, you may want to skip out on small places with high(ish) entry fees attached. Don't in this case! The Samurai Museum is 1800 yen/person, but for that, you get a semi-private and very enthusiastic tour! Their collection is really nice, with a good range of samurai armor, katanas and other bladed weapons, and guns. For funsies, you get to try on a couple of helmets/costumes with the staff's help, and they're happy to take pictures of you.The tour was really informative, with a very knowledgable and adorably-enthusiastic guide. For most of the tour, it was just my husband and myself, though a couple of times, we ended up mixing with another group of 2-3.As a bonus, the guide found out we were on our honeymoon, and gave us two pairs of chopsticks on our way out - one with a samurai design, and one with a noble lady. :) It's the little things.Head's up: this museum is near Shinjuku's redlight district. It's totally safe to walk around there (including in their nicely-late hours), but don't get discouraged when you start seeing more bars and ...interesting signs.
History. If you like samurai history this is the place. you get to dress like a samurai take a picture and take a picture. Tour guide thru the museum after pass by the gift shop.Awesome souvenirs

Nice leafy area for a walk. This area is leafy and green during summer but I guess in Spring it would be much lovelier. Not all the venues are open free to the public, the one that is paid entry is well worth it. The souvenirs are great too because they are well made.

My favourite part of Japan!. This review will be biased as I love Samurai and the history they entail.This musuem was my favourite part of my Japan tour and I made the most of it.Very well priced for what they have; 1800 Yen and there is a vast variety of Samurai costumes some you can try on. The tour guide explained the the history of each artefact and back stories quite well.There were Samurai blades, armour, guns and even a life demonstration which I volunteered to be a part off.It is quite far but because the train systems are so brilliant in Japan we got there in two trains over 35 minutes, well worth it!

Samurai Museum. As my kids were obsessed with Samurai warriors, we decided to visit a museum relating. The exhibition was great, but the most interesting part is trying some costumes and taking some pictures. Additionally, we were very welcomed by the staffs, who guided us enthusiastically. A well-organized museum with great staffs.

Nice museum. As we were staying at the Shinjuku Gracery Hotel, it took us only a short walk to make it to the museum. The museum is small with two floors that include samurai related objects (some are reproductions, but still look impressive). Without the demonstration, the visit would not be worth it. However, as part of the demonstration, our son had the chance to try and learn sword handling and had an amazing time. That alone was worth the ticket price.

Very good small museum. I went here based on Tripadvisor reviews on a weekday evening. I was alone and found the place very easily using Google maps on my phone. It's right at the Kabukicho district along one of the smaller roads towards the back. The exterior looked really promising and I couldn't wait to get inside.When I entered, I was politely greeted by a few staff who showed me where to buy the ticket. Right after purchasing the ticket (Now 1,800yen), I was pleasantly surprised to find out that I have been provided a guided tour. Since I was the alone and noone else had arrived at the same time, my guided tour was one-on-one! My friendly guide was a young man, very energetic and enthusiastic (too bad I forgot his name!). We started out on the ground floor where there were real authentic Samurai warrior armour on display. He helpfully explained all the details which I never would have known if I had been on my own. Then we went upstairs - here there were a number of small rooms displaying various Samurai periphenalia. Everything was really interesting and my guide was very engaging, asking me lots of questions to test my knowledge and so that I can relate to the things he was explaining. In one of the rooms, the guide let me put on the face and headgear of a replica samurai armour. At the end, guests can put on kimonos and pose for photos for free. One of the highlights of my Japan trip! The gift shop didn't have much things that interested me but you can buy swords to be shipped home. They even provide a list of countries which do not allow swords to be shipped in, so you know. All in all, I had a great time here. I would have loved it to be a bit bigger with more exhibits!

Samurai Experience . Great little museum on samurai history, armor, and practices. Great guides with good knowledge and English. Sword handling performance and photo opportunities. Well worth a visit. Definitely get a guide (provided) and watch the performance.

Not just a museum visit, a great experience. I have to admit that when I arrived and saw the price and how small the museum was, I started to have second thoughts about going in but I'm so glad we did. Apart from the really amazing samurai armor and weapons, what really made it an experience was having one of the staff guide us around and being able to handle and try on a suit of armor. It was much more than just a museum visit, it was a great experience. Definitely recommended!

Surprisingly enjoyable and worthy. We stopped by here on the way to something else and it was getting late and we were getting lost. Decided to check it out with quite low expectations actually. And the price seemed really steep! ¥1800pp!! Then I realised it included basically a tour guide who ended up being hilarious and very much enjoyable while he didn't come off as trying to be funny at all. Really made it enjoyable for me and such good service he gave us (I am really bad at remembering names but if management is reading this: he's the young man who is starting studies at UC Irvine soon lol) so special thanks to him.Glad we did it and definitely learned quite some interesting facts that I would never have come across

Good stop. Worth the time and money. Stopped here as it seemed well liked on TripAdvisor and was of interest to me. The admission fee is fair 1800 yen (about $15). Upon arrival I was greeted and handed to a guide. All spoke very good English and answered questions easily. It's not a large museum and there isn't a lot of information printed but the guides are very helpful and full of information. Be sure to ask what you want and go with the guide. Also, check what time the Samurai demonstration is and make sure to go then. It makes the trip to the museum complete and worth the money. He usually performs in the afternoon on the hour.

Small but interesting, with English speaking interpretors. This small museum provides a more detailed look at the history and culture of the Samurai through a variety of displays of their armor and swords. It also provieds information on their rise and fall from political power.

Great museum with a personal guide!. This is an excellent museum with beautiful Samurai armour. When we arrived we were pleasantly surprised to find a guide waiting to take us through the museum and explain the different armour. At the end, there was also a little show - great experience and lovely people working there.

The best experience in Tokyo for us. So, we weren't sure if we wanted to go there or not, but said, why not. It looked so small from outside and when we entered it seemed like hardly anyone was there, then all of sudden all the workers showed up. Entrance fee was quite bit more than I thought it would be, and I was hesitant, but decided since we were there, we will go ahead and go. One of the guys attached himself as our guide and took us through the museum explaining all the history and everything behind items. It was really great! It is much bigger than what you think from outside and items are interesting and narrative from the guide makes it so much better. Exhibition was great and we could try on some of the costume and helmet. It was really wonderful experience and worth the money (I don't remember how much it was, maybe around $15?) I highly recommend it.

Small, but just enough to get a glimpse of old Japan. I really enjoyed this visit - museum is small and there aren't that many exhibits, but I frankly thought it was sufficient - after the 7th Samurai suit, do you really need to see any more? The guide was very helpful and tried to explain as much as he could. I love the old Japanese things and am fascinated by the Samurai culture, so seeing the suits, swords and hearing/reading some of the stories was really enjoyable. The gift shop has some interesting displays of swords (replicas), but if you are lucky they sometimes have real swords (300 years old!) for sale,and you can get to handle them with care.

Fantastic gem - don't miss this!. What a fantastic museum! We were guided by a young local historian and he brought the whole Samurai period to life. Really well done. An entertaining demonstration followed at 2pm. You can touch some of the exhibits and even wear one of the authentic helmuts. Well worth the 1800 yen for each adult (>12years) all inclusive.We were glad our boys are a bit too young to have noticed the distinctly seedy location you have to walk through to get there...
Nice historic trip. beautiful place, cheap to enter, easy to find, centrally located, must visit if you have an interest in samurais, lots of cool souvenirs to buy and you can take plenty of photos!!
Hot spot in Shinjuku. If u here in Shinjuku ... this museum u must visit!! eazy to find by google map..ticket all include Guide - costume Samurai and Samurai show ...

Museo Piccolo e ben organizzato. It is a clear example of how a museum can be small and with few masterpiece and yet very interesting and valuable.Museum is very small maybe 6-8 rooms in total, and there are not so many armors and blades, but it is very well organized and museum personnel take you to the tour, explaining in English, the meaning of the objects you see. The staff is really good, you can tell they love their job, they help you to take pictures and they even let you wear real Samurai helmets...Price, in my opinion is far too high 1800 JPY per person, just as reference national museum is 620 JPY, Golden pagoda in Kyoto 400 JPY, Kyozumidera in Tokyo 600 JPY.

Friendly staff and fantastic service. The price of admission seems a bit steep, but you do you get your own tour guide. The tour guide was fantastic and gave a great description of every artifact in the museum. There was also a nice demonstration of sword fighting as a samurai and a location to take your picture with a kimono.

Just go... it's mint. As an ignorant Englishman who barely has a word of Japanese, I was a little apprehensive - but reading the reviews on here convinced me that the guides would help me out.They were right.Informative, attentive and funny - they helped bring to life this fantastic collection of samurai paraphernalia.It's tucked away down a side street, so if you've not got data on your phone, make sure you know where it is before setting off - but I had a great hour and a half there for less than £20... which is pretty decent in this city.

Highly enjoyable and informative!. We really enjoyed our visit to the Samurai museum. Our guide was very informative and we learned so much more than we would have done without him. My advice to all visitors is to use him if you can rather than going around on your own. He was also very helpful in finding us a perfect place for dinner afterwards. Gift shop seemed reasonably priced for small mementoes. Highly recommend a visit.

Awesome . Great for the whole family! It's quite small but well worth the visit.Staff are very friendly and we had a guide who explained the whole history and the different styles of armour and swords.There was a demonstration by a Samurai swordsman who has been in training for 5 years ... Training everyday.
Great option for rainy day. Enjoyed all the history and samurai relics. Location is a little hard to find but with google map we made it! The personal tour guide was nice. Not crowded.

Excellent guided tour with cool pictures!. I went to the Samurai museum with my brother in the early afternoon after finding it on trip advisor the previous day. It costs 1800 yen just so you know, but it was worth every penny with our tour guide Gin! Definitely ask for a guided tour and try to get Gin because he was excellent and taught us lots of interesting history about samurai warriors. We also were able to take really cool pictures with a full samurai helmet, mask and sword!

Learned a lot in this Shinjuku treasure. Great work from the team to give great tours in English. I would recommend this to anyone, dates, families, alone. It's fun, it's interactive with the costumes, it's not that expensive. Don't be shy, try it out and check out some of the historic artifacts in this well designed museum

Wasted time and money . I have lived in Japan for more than 10 years. I thought this would be a good place to take visitors .....BUTToo expensive - $18 per person - no discounts for studentsThe staff is friendly and eager to offer explanations. However - because of the limited English ability - the explanations are lacking in details.The viewing room for the "Iai" show is small. It is crowded and very disorganized. And no explanation of what the show is about. Except - welcome to a "samurai demonstration".The museum desperately needs to hire a historian and a curator. Until then, this is a trap for unsuspecting tourists.

A must do!. We had a brilliant time at the Samurai Museum yesterday. We got a (free) guided tour of the museum, which includes both authentic (some 400+ years old) and replica samurai attire. We also saw (at 2:00pm), a samurai demonstration by a 'samurai actor' - it was great! The staff are absolutely delightful. 1,800 yen per adult - definitely worth it.

Anything but a boring museum. What a great experience and interesting place to visit. Get a personal guide to explain what you are seeing, try on an uniform, get a photo (included in the price), and even experience a live demonstration by a master.

Small, Wonderfully Curated Museum. Really great way to spend an hour or two in the afternoon. The staff are very helpful. As others have mentioned, wait to catch one of the free guided tours as the museum is light on textual descriptions of the historical context surrounding the pieces.

Small but interesting museum. My boyfriend practices iai so I was interested in this museum. It's small, but they have a lot of great items on display. A guide met me at the beginning of the second floor exhibits and provided a lot of additional information about the items on display. I'm sure this museum will get even better with time as they accumulate more items.

View, try on and get a picture!. This little museum turned out to be our favorite stop in Tokyo!! It did take the cab driver a little while to figure out the location, but he kept asking local people to help. After arriving, the entrance fee was $18 per person (USD) and well worth it!! You could see all the original samurai complete outfits and a personal guide explained all the exhibits to you in English! There were even small rooms of the actual swords they used and pistols/guns! They had a place where you could try on the head gear and take pictures with your own camera, or if you have extra time, you can dress up in complete samurai outfits and kimonos and they will take your picture, for a fee (like the old west pictures that are taken in the US.) The guide had a very in-depth knowledge of the history behind the displays and everything was so interesting. Definitely a must see!!

Very good. Quite steep entrance price of ¥1800pp but worth it once inside. All the staff spoke good english and took small groups round explaining the history of each piece and period displayed. The suits of armour all looked brand new despite being hundreds of years old. Tried on some helmets and swords and watched the show which was interesting and involving. Learnt a bit and enjoyed our visit.

I simply loved it. Plenty of knowledgeable staff willing to guide you around and talk you through the exhibits and their history, chances to view beautiful replicas of all the famous suits of armour and actual historical pieces too. Then we got to play dressup.
A great way to spend a couple of hours
A museum worth visiting. A nice excebition. The guide tried hard to answer questions the best he could. I reconmend waiting for a free tour because most display text is in japanese.

Small samurai museum. A very small, privately-owned samurai museum located very near to the Shinjuku station. There are 2 levels of exhibits, with a few samurai attire, swords, paintings. Costs Yen1800/pax to view, which I felt was expensive for the small exhibit. Positive point is that there is a staff to guide you through the exhibits with some explanations.

A Hidden Gem. Found this place through TripAdvisor. Its tucked away in a little corner of Shinjuku district. While the museum is small, you get the attention of a museum guide which comes at no extra costs!Amazed at the samurai costumes which are hundreds of years old! There is also a samurai performance but it would have been better if there had been some form of narration to go with the performance.

Excellent Samurai museum. This was another attraction I added after reading Trip Advisor. It was well worth the hour we spent in here. Its fairly small but packs in a plethora of education and amazing artifacts up to 500 years old. There is exquisite original Samurai armor as well as swords and guns. The staff are extremely friendly and knowledgeable. Make sure you don't miss up the dress up opportunity at the end of the tour!

A secret treat. This little museum is tucked away near the Golden Gai district in Shinjuku a block away from the busy section. It contains a personal collection of Samurai armor and weapons. They have a demonstration of Samurai fighting techniques that is very well done and authentic without a lot of the popular gimmicks and you can pose in Kimonos and Samurai armor for pictures. Its a great way to learn about the Samurai and was a lot of fun too.

Nice place for those who likes Samurai History. At the begining we were not aware about this museum, we went because we wanted to do something different in our last day in Tokyo, when we arrived the personnel was very kind and welcoming, there was a man that did a tour of the rooms and explained to us a little of history without any extra charge, we could take some pictures with some samurai suits, touch the swords, helmet and there was a show of swords in which we could participate very enjoying, we recommend this place to those who wants to see things of Samurai

Guided tour!. It's a very small but very interesting and nice museum.The entrance is 1800 yen for adults. Every now and then there is a guided tour. I highly recommend to wait at the entrance for a guided tour! The tour was very nice and informative. If we went by our own we would probably be finished within 30 min.In the museum you can dress up like a samurai or a geisha. And at certain times (ask for this!) they do a samurai performance (~15 min).This place might be a bit hard to find, so use Google maps!

Tetsuro-san's samurai museum. The mazes of Tokyo's Kabuki-cho are an unexpected place for a Samurai Museum, but in my opinion this is the number one attraction in the area. Tetsuro-san started the museum in 2015, to share his personal collection of ornate samurai artifacts and his extensive knowledge with the public. He's a very thoughtful and down to earth person, and gave me and a friend from Taiwan an amazing tour through his museum - allowing us to feel and try on many of the pieces. It was really fun and at the end of the tour I was so immersed that I had to rub my eyes to remember that it is the year 2016. I was already having a great time, but it became one of my best memories of the trip when Tetsuro-san took me and my Taiwanese friend to a small Izakaya for drinks after the tour, and I was in great company. I guess he couldn't do that for every visitor, but it just shows what a truly lovely person he is. The samurai museum is a lot of fun and the host is a one of a kind.

Superb. This is a gem in shinjuku a throughly good experience. The majority of the exhibits were authentic some 400 500 years old even had similar samurai swords. Which says something about the quality. I had personal guide throughout which is free you just paid small entrance fee. The guide knew his history great to see someone so enthusiastic. The exhibits were stunning some of the best ever seen. The other great thing is you get to try on replica armour and clothes the full lot and have photo opportunity. Great place well worth visit but take a taxi not easy to find

The Guided Tour is Informative. This is a small museum but it is bery educational to us foreigners to learn abt samurais. Staff would not leave you alone but to give you explanation of the exhibits and history. We can also put on the samurai armours and enjoy the demonstration. Highly recommended!

Small museum. Small display of Samurai objects from armour and swords.
There is a Samurai demonstration offered at selected times during the day which is well worth catching. The exhibition we saw was performed by Mr Hattori who was excellent.

Hidden Gem. The Samurai Museum is awesome. The staff is super friendly and informative and you basically get a private docent. They put on a great Samurai demonstration. The gift shop is great; we purchased a sword replica and they shipped it for us. The Samurai armor clearly demonstrates the inspiration for Star Wars.
Interesting!. We liked the Samurai Museum. However, we did not know that guided tours were available and only stumbled on one half way through. The guide was really good!
Must visit.. You should visit this place, you will get a guide that Tells you about the artifacts and about the history of samurai. You can also buy sword and t-shirt etc.

Worth it. It was nice, i kept on getting there later on at night. They close at 9pm. And there are shows earlier during the day. So I had toCome back the next day to get in there earlier. And it's behind the red light district area so don't get distracted. But once you get there, you'll learn a lot. And as many other people said, you get to do hands on!

Great museum. Loved the samurai show. Staff were excellent! Highly recommend!. The samurai museum was great to visit. Especially when you are learning all about the culture. What really made the museum was the staff. They walked us around different exhibits and explained everything. Thank you so much!

Must see . The entrance fee was worth every Yen! For a privately owned museum, not only was the display rich and diverse, the Samurai exhibition was amazing! They even had a private tour guide to explain the rich Samurai history. We would like to make special mention of Shu (I hope I spelled it right), who really did a splendid job of explaining and making us visitors more interested in the rich culture.
Nice place. great place to visit and see the samurai swords and armours but need improvement on history and presentation . I like the show though...

Small but mighty museum. A lot of samurai artifacts in this small museum. The best part was the gentleman that provided the guide service (no extra charge). Not sure if he was the owner or what, but he knew his stuff.. very interesting. Also at the end there was a samurai demonstration. You must go here.

Wonderful museum-highly recommend. This was a highlight of our trip to Tokyo. Our tour guide was so informative and made our visit so pleasant! We had many children in our group and our kind docent made the stories so interesting, and answered all of the children's questions. The samurai museum was extremely organized by period, so you are able to follow the history, then shop at the nice gift store at the end of the tour. Everyone enjoyed this very much and it was interesting for all ages! We met the owner and he was so kind to everyone. We can't wait to receive our samurai sword that we had shipped to our home! Thank you to everyone at the Samurai Museum. We will never forget our pleasant visit!

A Hidden Gem. Not the easiest to find, but find it and you will not regret it. Make sure you request a guide to take you through the small but very thorough museum. Our guide spent over an hour taking us through Japan's history and its relation to the Samurai - a very personable man, who took his time to articulate everything in a way that us lazy westerners could understand (My Japanese is very very limited) using Google to help explain or answer some of our questions. I also had the opportunity to learn basic Samurai skills by a man trained in the ways of the Samurai. Our initial reaction was that the price was expensive compared to other tourists spots (Ueno Zoo for example), but it was worth every penny. Great museum, supported by an enthusiastic staff with genuine knowledge and history of the subject matter.

Cool experience!. Had fun visiting with my husband. There is a tour guide to explain this small museum's exhibits. At the end of the tour they provide kimonos for men and women to take photographs. Would definitely recommend it !
Cool place to visit. Small museum very much worth a visit for an hour or two. The staff are knowledgeable and have good humour and the displays are very impressive

Felt like Tom Cruise in the last samurai. There is so much to see when your in Tokyo, the sights, the culture, the history, so on and so forth. Beauty at every corner. As we planned our Japan trip, I came across the museum and wanted to take some time to visit it.The museum did not disappoint, it is not expensive, it's not very large, and doesn't take a lot of time. There is so much knowledge and history at the museum, as you go through the museum one of the friendly staff members walks with you and explains to you the various samurai gear and history behind the swords.
