The gentleman that was with us, was very knowledgeable, was a great experience.At the end of the tour, you get to dress up, hold some weapons and feel like your a samurai.Take the time, make sure this is one of your stops. You wont come across any other samurai artifacts or history while your in tokyo. Where else you going to hold a samurai sword?

Beautiful suits of armour. Really great place to visit. The staff are polite. Knowlegable staff who speak descent english. They are polite and eager to educate. Fun for all ages. Small and easy to walk through. The picture posing in gear was fun. Easy to find. A bit pricey at 1800¥.

Worth taking the time to visit. theres plenty to see and do in Shinjuku and this is worth taking an hour out to visit. Its quite a small place but the staff are very knowledgeable and keen to explain the history of the exhibits. Theres a twice daily demo of sword techniques with chances to interact at the end.

A must go for samurai lovers. This place is in the famous area of Shinjuku so just stop by when you go there. You pay for enternace fee then you go inside for personal tour with a japanese guide. There is a samurai show every 1 hour and the staff will tell you if you wana watch it. You can try several samurai helmets and clothes. the musem is small and can take 2 hours most
Interesting little museum . A small but very interesting museum. Cost is 1800 yen but you get a guided tour in English. I had a blast and learnt a few things

Tokyo gem. After almost a week of a wonderful experience in Tokyo, we stumbled across this museum. It's amazing, small, super interesting and everyone there was kind and helpful, all our questions were answered and there was a free guide throughout the museum. At the end, there's a Samurai show, interactive and entertaining. We have a very active and energetic 3 year old and a teenage daughter, we all had the best of times. The gift shop was well stocked, with lots of accessible presents to take home. This will be a fantastic memory. We don't usually write reviews, but this was such a fab experience we could not, not write a review.

Amazing artefacts and staff. We spent over 2 hours here even though it's a small place.
The staff were lovely and very attentive, We always had a staff with us explaining what we were looking at. The live show was also great.
The souvenir shop was affordable and great postage service internationally.
Highly recommended.

A take part experience. As well as walking the museum your fee will give you a sword demonstration and allow you to try on part of a uniform. At the end of the sword demonstration, the audience can take part and learn the moves with a wooden sword. The museum itself is quite small but still impressive, the staff will talk you through the exhibits and answer any questions. Be prepared to take off your shoes and possibly to sit crossed legged for the show.

Great experience for adults and children. Small but excellent new, modern museum. English speaking private tours and great written descriptions throughout museum. My kids loved it (especially 7 year old son) and we all enjoyed dressing up in kimonos and samurai clothing for pictures at the end. Far exceeded my expectations!

Museum of Armor and Weapons. In the heart of the sleazier section of Shinjuku (Host Bars to the left and right) is this unexpected treat. One of the pricer museums around (¥1800), its staff tries very hard to explain the pieces on display. We were followed by a nice guide who knew enough English to help us understand the armor, the weapons, and some of the people that used them in Japanese history. There are some authentic pieces, and a few reproductions. A nice addition was an actor who demonstrated a few moves with a katana sword. All in all, a nice break (with good air conditioning!) from the pressing masses outside. Nothing extravagant or jaw dropping...but worth your time.

Great place for the family. Our family had a great visit to the museum. While not being a huge museum it was very informative and the guide had a lot of knowledge on the history behind the artifacts on display. All the staff were very accommodating to my 4 and 2 year olds and we got lots of photos dressed in the traditional garments. The display by the Bushido practitioner was good too. On leaving my 2 kids got a plastic samurai sword each from one of the staff members and they loved it.

A little bit of history . Its quite a small museum but great i loved it the history. They have some really old pieces in there collection.We got to dress up in the traditional gear which was cool. The guide walked us around explaining about the pieces.We found a discount coupon in one of the travel guides. Make sure to pick some of them up they had discounts for quite a few places.

I love this place - don't expect too much. The group have really crafted an excellent experience that is simple and easy to navigate. The staff speak English and are friendly and enjoy sharing their knowledge. They had a display with a samuri in training who had amazing sword skills and a guide who would answer even the most esoteric questions. It was cute, quaint but well organised and you could dress up as a warrior or in a kimono - son loved it..

Fantastic place. Fantastic place for people, who are interested in samurai history. The owner is the guide and he allowed touch some things from exhibition. It's amazing! when you hold in your hand original Katana.

Samurai Goodness. Was a very cool experience. Owner is very nice, and my tour guide was also the bomb, he even showed me a great ramen spot to eat at afterwards. The armors are great and they have a good variety. The weapons were also equally as impressive. Will definitely be back. We were even able to try some of the helmets on! If you're going to be in Tokyo and want a taste of culture, this is the spot to go.
Really enjoyed it . Cool museum, bit small but with free personal guided tour, well worth a visit. Especially the sword demonstration is very Cool.

Interesting if you are into samurai or weapons/armor. I really enjoyed seeing the old samurai suits of armor and weapons, but what really made this trip fun for me was the sword kata demonstration. An experienced swordsman demonstrates the different sword stances and attack forms used by samurai in the olden days. It was really cool to get a live demonstration with a real samurai sword!

Fun and educational experience. This museum was close to my hotel so I thought I'd visit it as it seemed different to the standard temples and nightlife that had filled my itinerary. If you are interesting in history then this is a cool way to spend a couple of hours. The armour and swords are impressive and we were lucky enough to be able to try on the armour and take a photo free of charge (500 Yen normally). I would recommend this experience if you want something unique.

Impressive collection and fantastic guides. This museum is largely the personal collection of the owner. It's always wonderful to see people share these treasures with the world.They have a several sets of armor that cover a large set of history, as well as other swords and helmets. There was a guide who walked me through personally and explained the time periods and significance of what I was seeing. It was great.This isn't a large museum, but it's worth a stop. It takes about an hour, and you can put on a replica samurai helmet and see a demo of the sword handling. Each group was walked through individually and then guided to the demo. There were some kids in there who really liked that part (though it was funny to watch them cover their ears when the performer yelled with each stroke).
Great!. Staff was very nice and spoke English. They took the time to show me through everything. I will be coming back.

A Gem in Kabukicho. Oh this was just great. Authentic Samurai armor and gear mainly from the Edo period. There were some other cool artifacts like guns and horse gear. This is such a great addition to Kabukicho and the gift shop sells some awesome stuff. I mean it's the best gift shop ever.

Must see for Samurai devotees. My family and I visited the Museum in April 2016. The museum is somewhat difficult to find. We did need to ask for directions. Once there we were fortunate enough to see a live show. An actor displayed some of the stances and fighting techniques of the samurai. We were then able to look closely at the amour and swords in the various rooms. The attendants were on hand to answer questions and allowed us to try on the helmets and amour. They added a more personal touch. My 2 kids who weren't really into samurai seemed to also enjoy this experience. One disappointment though was the gift shop. Unless you were going to purchase a replica sword there wasn't much on offer. I would have thought an English book on swords or some sword key rings would have been good to have. Overall I would defiantly recommend this to anyone who is interested in samurai.

One of the. My two friends and I had a great time here. As university students on a budget, it was more expensive than most of the other admissions I had to pay this trip, but it was also one of the best experiences. Between the samurai show, seeing old equipment and dressing up with replicas, this place certainly packs a punch despite its somewhat small size. The dim lighting can make it difficult to take pictures, but fortunately some areas are specifically created for taking pictures when you try things on.Additionally, our tour guide was very enthusiastic and friendly. Once we completed the museum we spoke with the owner for close to an hour. He definitely takes a very personal interest in the museum and was polite and friendly as well.All in all, the visit lasted several hours and was worth every minute of it.

Interesting and friendly. We felt very welcome, and our tour guide was good in english and funny. Took totaly about 2 hours with the samurai show (included in the fee, wich was 1800y) The museum contains in smal rooms, the air is a bit bad, or filled with inscents. You have to take of your shoes on the second floor, and mind your head. A great visit on a rainy day!

Brilliant!!. Brilliant!! Unlike most museums a member of staff will guide you through each item in the museum and explains the history behind it. They will let you touch some of the items and get a photo with it too.There is also a sword demonstration every hour, at the end of which you can get a lesson.Very reasonably priced and worth every yen

Small but worth it. We took our 14 year old son, had a guide for the 3 of us and really enjoyed the museum. It's not very big but the guides do a great job of explaining the different swords & armour from the periods.
Small but worth it.. It's a small place but the guides are excellent. Definitely try on the armour and try and catch the sword demonstration.
Rich culture. This was only a last minute decision to go to the museum, but now glad we did. What an eye opener to history and things I never knew about. Good to see such passion in informing people.

Great museum. We found this place hard to find but when we did it was worth it. We got treated to a free private tour with a guide who, although didn't speak perfect English, tried his best to be as informative as possible.They were also kind enough to offer us a photoshoot for free, so my husband got to dress up as a samurai and I a princess, great fun! When they learnt we were on our honeymoon, they gave us a gift too! Really can't fault their service and hospitality.
Great experience. The staff is very friendly and explain everything . they let you try on the samurai clothes and take pictures. The armor on display are amazing. Recommend to go!

Very nice, recommended! :D. The museum has a very nice interior with tatami and nicely arranged swords and armors. We got a informative and nicely done tour and could even take pictures with samurai fashioned clothes :D We recommend to see the sword drawing show, it's been impressive! Also the staff was very friendly and helpful, thanks for the great experience!
interesting authentic place. interesting authentic place for those who are interested in Japan's history, the history of the samurai

Best hands-on museum in Tokyo!. Great exhibit of Samurai armor, swords, and culture including live demonstrations of samurai sword fighting techniques and the ability to try out swords and armor! Definitely worth the visit and happy to come back again with my son. Now if they could open up a ninja museum too, i would be in heaven!

Awesome samurai fight display and friendly staff. This was a highpoint of our trip to Tokyo. We arrived just in time to see the samurai sword fight display and it was awesome. The staff is really friendly and most of them have good and understandable english. Make sure you get a guided tour! We were shown around by a very nice young man and he told us about the different armors and swords and answered our questions. We got to try on some helmets and took pictures dressed in traditional samurai clothes. The ticket price might seem high but if you get the guided tour and see the sword fight display it is worth it. I loved all of it and will highly recommend it to anyone with even just a slight interrest in history and samurai.
Great experience. Very nice staff. great experience. you can try Samurai customs and watch Sumurai fighting styles. highly recommend to Tokyo travellers

Cool display of Samurai fighting technique!. The museum had both armor and swords used from 400 years ago with some armor even having wear and dents from battles. The display of the weaponry was amazing and included guns used during the samurai era. To top it all off, you see an amazing performance of a modern samurai who has undergone decades of training and get to interact with him afterwards asking anything you want! Really great museum with an extremely hospitalable staff who works there to guide and answer any questions!

Amazing museum!!. This place is fantastic, one of the best things we did in Japan. The guides are happy to wander with you if you would like explanation, or let you go to wander around yourself.A lot of the exhibits are authentic pieces, even with an 800 year old sword on display. It really is an amazing collection of artifacts.The guides also speak pretty good English.Photography definitely allowed and encouraged.Dress-ups are a good laugh too!Do yourself a favor and visit!

Great service staff, awesome Samurai swordplay. Initially me and a group of friends were wondering if we should go in, but it turned out to be the best thing ever! I got to try out wielding a sword and it was really fun. It's not a huge museum, but it's cosy and you get personal tours by the staffs there if you ask them, and they are really nice. The Samurai swordplay is really cool! Was really intense and awesome to see the actor wielding it right before my eyes. You should definitely visit it, just for fun and to know more about SAMURAIS!

Wonderful!!. Me and my friends've been there at the right time of Samurai show starting and it was really great! Besides exhibition is really interesting. They arranged Samurai armours, swords, paintings etc. by the timeline of Japanese history so we know more about history. Staff are really nice and can speak English fluently.

Definitely a must see if you're going to Tokyo! . If you are even relatively interested in Japan's samurai culture, I highly recommend you visit. The Japanese are known to be hospitable and helpful, but this place goes over and above the norm. Staff will eagerly give you a guided tour of the place, explaining what each piece is and whose armor is on display, will give brief histories of battles painted on the walls and even how famous the generals. If you already know the names: Nobunaga Oda, Ieyasu Tokugawa, Yukimura Sanada, Shingen Takeda, Kenshin Uesugi, Kanetsugu Naoe, Masamune Date and Hideyoshi Toyotomi, then you're in for a treat, you can find amazing replicas of their armors here. The guides also do their best in explaining everything in English, to the best of their ability of course, and they're pretty good English speakers compared to a lot of locals. The ticket is even good for a return visit so you can watch their live Samurai show and ask questions! I personally came back to the museum myself, and it is totally worth the walk. If you can speak Japanese like myself, then you're in for a treat because then you'll find out really how well the staff members know their stuff. They know more about the history than those of the samurai on display, and you can even trade stories about your favorite samurai and theirs. They also know a lot about the history of the warring states period such as Oichi being the most beautiful in the land, and contrary to some media, that she didn't actually fight in any battles with a toy or battle hoops. I closing, I would say definitely check this place out because of how well the museum treats it's guests, how knowledgeable the staff are, and how beautiful the things on display are. You can even touch some of them!
Amazing. This place is amazing. Learning about the history of the samurai and you are able to take pictures here. The tour guide was great. The place lets you put some of the samurai head armor on.
On of the best museum. Amazing place, with museum tour you can try armors and weapons, the show at the end is amazing seat on the front for sensations.
いいミュージアムです!!. you can see and known all about samurai history at this nice museum!!! if you lucky you can see "samurai show" recomended place in tokyo !

Wonderfull.. 素晴らしいSubarashī!While not as large as the edo museum if you love museums, ancient Japanese culture - history and or all thing's samurai related this is a must. Quality not quantity is the key and the staff are polite, helpful and just amazing. Some speak a little English.It's suitable for the whole family although is also open late. please ask your hotel for directions as some taxi drivers and senior locals will not help. They do not wish spent send people to an adult-entertainment and bar area although I have seen many family's their during the day and like London's Soho it's not as bad as it once was. It's pretty safe during the day and Japan's police have since cleared up the area. There's also plenty of other charming non adult attractions there. most x rated stuff is well shielded away. I can't say it enough the staff here and superb and helped me out with a problem recently. there's an opportunity for free photo's in replica samurai gear and there's a samurai actor who does a great performance. Go there it's worth it.
Unique visit. Great little private museum dedicated to samurais and their history. Tours by passionate and friendly guides who are more than happy to answer any questions.

Fantastic museum with personal tour guide. I can't speak highly enough of this museum! Our guide Su had a great knowledge of everything in the museum, the demonstration was fun and interesting and it was a lot more than I was expecting from a personal collection of artefacts. If you love history and getting absorbed into a story then go along to this little gem of a museum.
Interesting. This is a cozy interesting museum, with passionate staff and owners who will try to explain the details behind each armour. It's quite pricey, but the exposition is nice.

Fascinating Collection. A beautiful museum with great insight into Japanese ancient samurai culture. It has only been open 6 months but already seems to display a large range of attractions for a small private museum. Suits a range of ages, from kids to adults.They have a great private tour guide who is very informative about all the exhibits. Many of the second floor exhibits (such as helmets and face masks) you can try on and take photos. The highlight was the real samurai sword technique demonstration.

Amazing tour guide went above and beyond. The tour guide was amazing, so nice and informative - really made the experience amazing. Awesome swords, armour, muskets, a sword show, and got to dress up in traditional style costumes. Highly recommend!!!

small museum but worth a visit. charming little museum, great opportunity to admire the Samurai Armor in close distance and in details. can get a chance to dress up as a Samurai to take a photo with your own camera. many nice souvenirs to buy at the ground floor shop as well, worth the visit.

Did I just walk through red light district?. We were using google maps to find this place and I think it is located in the red light district or something. There were posters with half naked people and signs with things like Love Room or massage posters of women in thongs. I couldn't explain to my daughter why 6 or so men were on a board naked with there private parts covers. So awkward. Anyway, the museum is quite small but my husband loved looking at all the different armor and swords and guns. We were on a tight time schedule but stayed for the samurai show. I expected more. I didn't expect to be in a room that was so quiet you could literally hear a pin drop. The show was basically a samurai doing different poses with a sword. Slow movements and maybe only two words which were "hai" screamed loudly. It was neat to see but way to long for it being that slow.

Small museum complete with swordplay demonstration. Like the title says. A bit touristy and on the small side, but I spent a wonderful hour in there. That might be due in part to my passion for all things samurai-related. If this is not something which interests you, but still want to look at some armours and weapons, I still recommend going, but I advise keeping your expectations low. There are regular demonstrations by an actor / katana master which are short and sweet.

Mixed feelings.. I had mixed feelings about it -- I am naturally skeptical of everything and the number of things that seemed like replicas, particularly the canvases and artwork, felt a bit off. We had a young lady give us a guided tour, but she seemed to only be able to stick to her script and wasn't really able to field most of the questions we had. Maybe it was a language thing, but I'm not so sure. The whole thing felt a bit amateur, so Samurai Museum is probably a generous term. Even so, we got to try on some "authentic" -- dubious, but whatever -- samurai gear, hold a katana, and watch a short demonstration by a modern samurai of the different stances. Worth the price of the cheap admission.

Small Secret in Shinjuku. Not a huge museum...basically the Owner of this place managed to retrieve loads of Genuine Samurai Antiques...2 floors to be precise..The staff are friendly and knowledgeable. The best part is that u get to wear the samurai gear... highly recommended..

Very cool and authentic display . It's a small and neat museum with about an hour stay. 2 floors of original (and some even more than 400 years old!) samurai swords, armor and clothes. You get a guided tour included in the 1,800 yens, and get to wear some armor and try a cool helmet.

A Great Experience. It was a rather small museum but still a great experience. You can take photos of all the armor. On the second floor, you get to see more armor, helmets, and swords. Side note: you have to take off your shoes on second floor, so wear some comfortable socks. I enjoyed having a guide tell us about the history behind certain pieces. Also make sure to stay for the samurai sword shows. You can take pictures of the guy as he poses with samurai sword before doing a little show, roughly 15 minutes. I also got a mini samurai to take home from the gift shop. Overall an experience you don't want to miss.

Something different . My partner loves Samurai history, so after a long search for this museum as its not easy to find, we expected more historical and advanced insight to the samurai. Although it was small and had serval intimate rooms to view up close the original tools, swords and armour: the guide lacked knowledge beyond average so was unable to answer any of my partners questions. The show seemed like a good idea and was what sold the ticket to the museum to us as its quiet expensive. The man who performed didn't mention any history, or explain his motions. He just performed slow movements like fighting stances for almost an hour which got a little tiring if I'm honest. We were expecting friendly sparing between two samurai fighters in armour or something more informative. Although we were pleased we had at least found it after our search and did enjoy seeing the display, not recommended unless you have knowledgeable interest into the samurai and money to burn.

Great museum with a free guide. The museum is centrally located and easy to find just off the main streets. After paying to go inside we were joined by a guide who took us around the museum and explained all of the items to us. I didn't expect this and it was free of charge which I thought was great and the guide was very informative. In the gift shop you can but a Samurai sword and have it shipped back home - I did this and it arrived a few weeks after me. Its a great souvenir and you can track the delivery online. Please be aware that shipping will cost just under what the sword did and when it gets to customs (UK) you will pay £30 to have it released due to taxes.Overall this museum is well worth a visit and great value.

Great Museum. This museum is a great way to see Armour and Swords of the Samurai. The guided tour is great and is a good way to ensure that people know what the several artefacts are about. The samurai display show at 2, 3 and 4pm are worth seeing so I recommend that you plan to visit around these times. You will only need 30 mins for the guided tour part and then around 15 mins for the show. The entrance price may appear to be on the high side but remember that you are supporting the display of the owner's private collection and not some big business. Worth the visit if you are interested in Samurai and some history of Japan.

Quaint little museum but lacks information. The staff were friendly and accommodating; they did their best to explain exhibits in English although the information they provided was limited. On the 2nd floor, you are even allowed to touch and put on some of the exhibits to take pictures with. There's also a little photo corner where you can dress up as well. However, their collection is rather small and the information on the plaques regarding each exhibit was not very informative. Unless you already have a general knowledge of the Sengoku period, you wouldn't actually understand much. The 2nd floor has a small section for the Bakumatsu but again, there was not much information that explained who Sakamoto Ryoma is and what he did, or much on the Shinsengumi. It would not take long to go through this museum but overall still worth a visit.

Fascinating little museum. Visited here with my 12 yr old daughter and 10 yr old son. The museum is quite small, but the exhibits are genuine and quite fascinating. Plenty of really helpful staff around to provide some explanation and background to the various pieces on display. Lots to interact with too, with helmets and robes to try on and posed photos to take. We also had a sword drawing and form demonstration from a sword master with Q&A afterwards. One of the highlights for my kids in our short stay in Shinjuku.

Excellent museum. Insightful.. I thought that this museum might be a bit hammy but I was wrong! They have original weapons and armour as well as excellent modern reproductions made in a traditional way with genuine materials. It is tastefully displayed. The best thing is that you are personally conducted through the facility by a genuinely knowledgeable guide who speaks perfect english and really brings the Samurai, their life-style, and detailed history to life. Open in the evening. Has special options including calligraphy lessons with an expert and photo sessions where you can don the Samurai outfit.

My kids loved it!. I was the least interested in visiting this museum out of everyone in my family, but I was very pleasantly surprised. My kids enjoyed the Samurai demonstration and being able to try on helmets and clothing. It was a little pricey as we there less than 2 hours, but it was a truly unique Japanese experience.

charming little museum. quite small but charming, you can stay as long as you want to looking into the details of Samurai armors, you are allow to take photos but not videos, worth a visit, you can dress up to take a photo with your own camera free of charge.

Very informative and fun experience.. After looking at Tripadvisor, we decided to visit this museum. I'm so glad we did!We went at around 7:30/8 pm, and used Google Maps to find it down a side street in Shinjuku. We found it we only a few other visitors, and were fortunate to have an extremely knowledgeable guide who explained so much history to us. His stories actually provided context to some of the other tourist attractions we visited around Tokyo (e.g. Meiji Shrine in Harajuku). We also had some much fun dressing in the traditional costumes! Our guide took our photo for us, and he did a great job. Many other reviews say it doesn't take that long to go around, but if you have the right guide and patience to read all the displays, then it takes about an hour to see everything. I definitely recommend you visit this museum!

Tokyo highlight. This is a small and inconspicuous museum in the heart of Shinjuku. It's not cheap but is worth every yen. The guides are good and very well-informed but, if you can take the tour with the owner you will have a fascinating experience. Don't miss this.

Samurai history comes alive!. This small gem of.museum is located in what appears to be a typical Japanese house. There are English speaking guides who escort you around the two small floors, and several times each afternoon a Japanese actor who often portrays a Samurai warrior gives a 15 minute demonstration. All exhibits also feature extensive, multi-lingual signage (including English).The museum is a welcome distraction from the glitz and glitter of modern Tokyo, and provides some insight into the importance that the Samurai played in ancient Japanese history. Numerous displays of Samurai armor, most of it genuine, as well as swords and other components of Samurai culture are also displayed.There are some interesting and different items for sale in the small gift shop as well as authentic antique swords for sale (you do have to ask about them).Anyone even remotely interested in Japanese history and culture should make this new museum a must!

Fantastic palce to visit.. Didn't know what to expect as we went to visit on impulse.The staff were very friendly and informative with many superb exhibits.When we went upstairs we were greeted by the owner who was a lovely old gentleman.He was very passionate about his collection and was very interesting to talk to.He even opened some of the locked cases, took out helmets and rifles and allowed me to handle them.What other museum would ever do that?Thoroughly enjoyed our visit and if you are in the area I would say give it a visit and see some fantastic exhibits.

Small museum but worth a visit. Spent about hour and a half at the museum. Small museum with a small shop. We didn't stay for the demonstration of sword use but we were told by staff our tickets was valid if we wanted to come back later that day to see it. Very interesting and informative. Staff will use your camera so you can get photos of you beside the displays. Also get a chance to try on some outfits with staff using your camera and taking photos of your experience. Would recommend this museum.

Great little gem. Great little evening excursion, really interesting and staff were exceptionally friendly and helpful. We were show around by a lovely chap who told us about the history and importance if the pieces in the museum. It's not a massive museum and for around $20 aud maybe a little on the $$$ side, but the tour and dress up at the end were lots of fun.
Recommend.. Recommend. A bit expensive. Staff is kind and gentle. There is animation and is ok for children above 5.
Not what we expected. . This is a very small collection. We thought it was quite expensive for what it was. We saw stayed for the show which was average.

Couldn't be better. This is the example of how a museum not necessarily need to be huge to be great.Very back to basics and the essences of the content, this Samurai Museum will take you to the medieval Japan, will explain and briefly show you the various examples of armoires that real Samurais wore at the time, as well as the weaponry.Me an my family really enjoy the experience, the staff very professional, friends and helpful, they look after us and my one your kid offering use a premium assistance, perhaps my Kia was so excited.The best part is when you are allow to wears the armor and take some shots with it, including a katana non-sharpened replica.Arigato gosaimasu, we really love it.

Quaint little museum. There were a few different displays but you should know that it is not big. A guide walks through the exhibits with you and tells stories and explanations in relatively good english. Most of the displays look like they are replicas but still cool to see up close.

Not for people on a budget. The exhibition is beautiful, albeit limited. The sections are separated, so you have a very private feeling when you receive the guidance. Also, the photo opportunities are a nice touch, when to you get the chance to pose as Samurai after all.Unfortunately, the information on the placards is very limited and the guide didn't add much to it. His English was sufficient and he was nice young lad, but I didn't get a lot of overview of the Samurai culture and history. I am history buff though, so my standards probably are very high in that regard.Did not get to see a sword show on a Sunday night. Perhaps it would be good to post a comprehensive list of the included items at the ticket.If you are in the area and your budget isn't tight, you can't to wrong. If you love samurai culture and want to see some items up close it is also a good spot. Otherwise there is Samurai items in the Tokyo museum, that probably will be enough for you. For me it was OK but overpriced. I'd rather have comprehensive placards and a lower price than a personal tour.The Samurai swords in the shop looked pretty cool though and they ship them now.

Well worth a visit. We loved this place. After getting off the subway we wondered slightly where we'd ended up as the area seemed a little seedy but after a short walk we found the Samurai Museum. The staff were very welcoming and friendly. They gave my son a mini samurai sword toy to keep him happy and have us additional information on all of the displays in English. The museum itself is quite small but very interesting to see and my husband much enjoyed taking part learning the samurai moves and also dressing up. I'd definitely recommend it.

A smaller museum, but a great attraction. I visited this museum during the first week of April, and was quite impressed by the thorough knowledge of the staff. Our guide spoke English very well and really helped bring this interesting aspect of history to life. The samurai demonstration was outstanding, and I was lucky enough to be allowed to help demonstrate some of the poses along with the expert. The photo op at the end of the tour is worth the wait. A most enjoyable visit - not cheap, but worth the money for the experience.
Terrific.. We loved our visit to the museum. It is small, but the staff are great and the show was informative. We had a lot of fun trying on the costumes and posing with the swords.

Great place to visit. well, the place is small but full of knowledge, costumes, Swords, Guns...etc specially their mini show is great. audience can ask question after the show and practice with real Samurai man!!!

Nice detour from Shinjuku. This part of town is very young and happening but this museum is a nice change of pace. The building itself is not very large but it contains several historic samurai body dressings and associated weaponry. When I visited there was a guide who spoke English and explained things in the different rooms upstairs with regards to Japanese history and the context of the things you were looking at. Additionally, the free samurai performance was impressive and had an English translation. Overall, if you are interested in this portion of Japanese history I would definitely recommend. The price is a little high considering the size of the museum but there is a lot of interesting things to see and learn.

Absolutely worth it. . We went in to see what sort of armour they had on display and were amazed to find original sets, as well as weapons. Everything is displayed beautifully. The staff are incredibly nice and our guide was very passionate about the pieces. We had to leave early, but we will be back! Do this.
Worth a Visit. Great Place, We were lucky enough to get a tour by from the curator. Defiantly a must see! when in Tokyo.

Great hour spent learning about samurais!. We spent about an hour at this museum. We got to try on the samurai head gear and watch a katana demonstration by a professional actor who has been studying it for 10 years. The contents of the museum were beautiful and the information surrounding the samurais was very interesting. I highly recommend this museum.
Well worth a lool. It's a very small place and you can pretty much see it all in about 30 minutes but it is definitely worth a visit. So glad that we came across this place.
Great for a rainy day. Small but interesting enough. Our kids enjoyed this with the samurai skills demonstration plus the chance to dress up. Highly recommended .

Worth the visit!. It was very informative getting to know different types of samurai living throughout in ancient Japan. My husband got a chance to put on the samurai face guard! You'll definitely benefit from it if you get a guided tour! You'll get a change to take pictures of yourself wearing prince/princess with accessories. Not taken by profession but it was good enough (:

Small, quality museum. Some will scoff at the ¥1800 admission but I found it well worth it. Our courteous tour guide allowed us to browse the exhibits at our leisure and introduced each display only when he noticed we were ready for the next one. The exhibits were all well laid out with a room holding a handful of artifacts with descriptions. Some were lacking in more detailed information and that's when our guide graciously provided some background. The displays themselves were of very high quality and definitely gave you a sense of the power, fear and respect each of the wearers'/wielders' garnered. One of the highlights is definitely being given the opportunity to wear a genuine general's helmet, faceplate and a sword. It really gave you a sense of the weight of it and how strong they would have to be to wear the entire ensemble. The sword demonstration held multiple times a day was also very entertaining and luckily if you happen to just miss one you can come back and see the next as long as you present your ticket. The small gift shop had some replica swords (which I admittedly was tempted by) for what seemed like a reasonable ¥6000-7000. Make sure you take into consideration the shipping and customs fees which a sign indicates the staff will help you sort out. I highly recommend this museum if you have an even passing interest in samurai history (and cool armour and weapons).

Excellent place . Great small museum. Used google map to locate this beauty or otherwise it will be bit hard to find . The staff was really friendly and they gave us a guided tour explained what exhibits were all about . You can even try out samurai helmet and a carry sword and take pictures . They also had this show case by a apprentice samurai which was cool . So ask the ticket counter the time of that performance.

Compact, but packed with incredible items and a great staff. This museum is small and is somewhat out of place compared to its neighbors (massage parlors, etc.) but once you find it itll make the experience worth it.The place is small, but has many interesting items. To be honest, I think the friendliest, most knowledgeable and most enthusiastic staff is this museums.I also got to see a katana demonstration, very cool. If you are in Shinjuku or around and like Samurais or culture, this is a great way to spend a couple of hours.

If you like to know more about samurais . Yeah first thing it's not obvious to find. We passed it 3 times. It's opposite some gorilla sign post. Ok so the museum is pretty much what you expect, paintings, armour, swords, etc. It's abit short and small but you get to play semi dress up
Great staff. It's a rather small museum. But the staff is really friendly and took time to explain all showed pieces. Even had the chance to try on a replica of a samurai uniform.

Great experience!. Opens at 10:30, and was taken around the museum by one of the guides named So who was fantastic! He was very knowledgable, spoke English very well and made the experience very interesting and fun!!

Samurai Museum in Shinjuku. It's a small museum in Shinjuku. Easy to locate with Google maps.Entrance fee is 1800 yen per person The samurai museum is really good you can find artifacts such as old helmets, old swords and old guns and you can see the samurai show.The staff was really helpful, knowledgable, passionate and frien.

very interesting.. The samurai museum is really good with interesting artifacts such as old helmets, old swords and old guns and more that were very interesting and old.The staff was really kind to us and our guide took time to explain the stuff and even brought us to the train station, which was really nice of him.overall, its a really nice place to have a look at for about an hour!

Samurai museum in Shinjuku is a must visit. Samurai museum was a great experience for our family (6 adult and 2 children). We were guided by an english speaking man whi did his best to explain the history and the meaning of all those swords and armours. The real samurai show was amazing. He did kinda "samurai kata" and we could ask questions and take pictures. Even getting dressed as an samurai was free of charge. Mr. Tetsuro-san who is the owner is the kindest person and showed us very good service. This place feels relaxing and intimate. A must visit when you are in Tokyo.

Immerse in rich history. Immerse yourself with the rich history that Japan has to offer - particularly in the world of the Samurai.This museum isn't very big but it is full of amazing artifacts including armor that dates back to over 400 years ago. The Samurai armor and weapons are kept in perfect condition and presented beautifully - you can also get right up and close to them to see every intricate detail that was put into the crafting of these artifacts which should be classed as art!The experience at the museum was enhanced as the guide allowed us to wear a real samurai helmet and hold a katana for photos - really giving us a feel of what it was like to be wearing the armor.Very rich in history and conveniently located in the middle of Shinjuku - in my books this place is not to be missed if you love history.

Fun museum!. We were there about a month after opening. The staff really took the time to explain items and history. They clearly want to share Samurai culture with visitors. Some replicas and some authentic Samurai uniforms and weapons. Enjoyed the museum.
Educational and entertaining.. Lots of original costumes and weaponry on display with knowledgeable and friendly staff to explain the exibits.

Worth having a look. Recently just opened so I can understand that there isn't much artefacts to look at, but worth having a peek. We were in and out within 20 mins. Staff were friendly and the atmosphere was chilled. Me and my girlfriend really enjoyed the little samurai performance, kind of scared her a bit. Hopefully in our return the museum will be expanded with plenty more to look at.

Over-rated and Overpriced . This was a pretty big let down. I thought there would be more of a collection. All the Samurai armor seemed not genuine, or I guess seemed replica. They do have some cool guns and some swords. A museum this size should cost 1000 yen max, not 1800. You can see everything in the museum in about 10-15 minutes.

Try on a Samurai helmet. It was worth the visit, but may a bit expensive. I enjoyed the exhibition and found the staff extremely helpful. The saving grace for this place is trying on a Samurai Helmet and posing for pictures while my wife was in a kimono and I was on a partial samurai kit.

Great way to spend an hour or two. Very interesting museum with an excellent collection of Samurai swords and dress. The tour guide is extremely knowledgable, passionate and friendly. This is highly recommended, even for those not necessarily interested in museums or Samurai history; it is just a great way to get a feel for Japanese culture and a fascinating era in it's history.

Great little museum brings samurai to life. Great little museum with a number of ancient artefacts. We had a young woman who took us round the museum and explained a lot of the history. There was also a demonstration of a ritual with a sword. After the demonstration they offer you the chance to get up and try. I volunteered and it was great fun wielding a sword. Overall well worth a visit.

Small but still Decent. My partner and I went in January, so being off-season there wasn't many people there. The staff there are very friendly and they do have differing levels of English. It is quite a small museum, which require you to take off your shoes in the second section, but it's well worth seeing all the different armours and how the clothing developed and hair style developed through the years. We tried to take our time to see all the different things, but we were probably out the museum within 45mins. I'm sure some people did it less than 10. Mainly because it's not that big and there could perhaps be more information of some of the samurais. However unlike may other places in Japan, you can try on the Samurai clothing, kimonos along with any props for free. The staff were also very willing to take photos of us,If you have some spare time and are in the area, I do recommend visiting.

No family discounts. It is nice but small. You go with a guide and get some information on the history of Japan. Possibility to dress up as a samurai for a picture. Only negative is the price for 4: 7200 yen is a bit too much (but no tip for the guide expected)

Small and highly over rated. This is a tiny two floor museum in a house in the bar district. It is not easy to find.Entrance fee is 1800 yen ($16 USD)The guides try their best but their English is limited.We are a martial arts family with over 50 years training between us and we were not overly impressed.If you want to waste half an hour and some money, go for a visit but I imagine that there are much better exhibits at local museums

Where history is brought alive. It's a small museum in Shinjuku. Easy to locate with Google maps. The entrance fee is Y1800 per person and well worth it. During our time there, there was a young Japanese guide who explained the first few rooms to us. My fifteen-year-old gets easily bored at museums, but even he was enthralled by the guide and how he brought the samurai history to life. The owner himself in the last room where he explained the history of the samurai right up to the "last samurai". The exhibits themselves are amazing. Many are not replicas but the real thing. It was a wet day outside. But inside, we were in the world of samurai.
Well worth it. Was a definite highlight of the whole trip. Not like a boring museum. Just a private collection of amazing original armours and weapons. A must see.

Small but worth a visit. The staff were very helpful and informative. They clearly care about the history of Samurai and enjoyed telling us about the various items on show, yet it didn't feel like they were following around or pestering us.If you're interested in Samurai, it's worth a good look.
I'm totally a Samurai now.. Got to put on the Samurai armor and swing swords around. Worth every penny! Cool neighborhood to stroll through as well.
Samurai museum Tokyo. Well worth a look. Staff are extremely helpful and informative. You. Can really get close to the exhibits.

A highlight of our trip!. My fiance and I went to this museum toward the end of our 3 week trip and it was fantastic! Definitely a highlight for us. The museum is situated in the Golden Gai, very easy to miss but not difficult to find if you have GPS (don't even need data, your phone should still update location without data). We were one of the first people to enter the museum that day and were lucky enough to score ourselves a guided tour with Gin. He was very friendly and explained the history behind each exhibit. We had many questions and he was able to answer almost all of them! We would have missed a lot of things without a guided tour so very glad they offered this service, without request or at an extra fee!There are a few exhibits that you are allowed to touch and some pieces that you are allowed to try on, which was awesome! We were allowed to dress up in some traditional robes without the 500 yen fee as the museum was very quiet and not many other guests were there. There was also a live show which we were too early for, but as long as you keep your admission ticket, you can return later in the day to watch it.A great place to learn a bit about Japan history, very lovely experience to cap off our trip. We even met the owner when we were browsing the souvenir store. My fiance bought a replica katana and the owner told us the history of the samurai that held the sword. I would definitely recommend a visit to this museum if you're interested in Japanese history!!

2007 and 2015 Visits. I visited the museum in 2007 and 2015; while the exhibits have changed, the quality does not. It's a niche audience and if you're willing to take a trip off the beaten path in Tokyo to visit, it's worth it for a view of Master level swordsmiths.

Authentic experience for samurai enthusiasts . I found this place on trip advisor and found out it had only been open for about 4-6 weeks before my visit and you could tell as everything felt quite fresh within the museum. The entrance is beautiful with a mini creek/stone steps sort of setting. It was a little quiet the day I went so I was able to be walked around the museum by one of the staff members who was an absolute legend. Explained everything about the weapons, armor, history of the Warriors and samurai. I can't recommend this place enough!!!
Awesome. For being in a strange part of shinjuku, this museum is a must see. Great tour, learnt alot, some amazing historical artifacts.Highly recommended

Fantastic info, really great guide. Recommended to anyone. We were guided by the owner of the museum, he speaks enough English to get all the message through and he has a wealth of knowledge about Japanese history and Samurai. Both my girlfriend and I thoroughly enjoyed the visit.

Cool. Me and my partner got there late and we just expecting to walk around on our own but we got a friendly guide who showed us about, it's not massive but some really cool exhibits definitely worth a visit

Great guide, great information!. We absolutely loved our time at this quaint museum! Our guide, gim, was very helpful and highly informative. He walked us through all the types of samurai attire as well as the swords and a brief history of japanese emporers and the samurai reign. We were allowed to wear traditional japanese attire as well and the whole experience surpassed our expectations. We highly recommend people check this place out

Fun little "museum" . We went there based on the the tripadvisor reviews we read before and it was definitely worthwhile to go.It is a small museum in the entertainment area of Shinjuku area. Just to walk around the area of the museum is already worth the trip!The museum itself is small and spread via two floors. You will need about 30 minutes to one hour to get through it. A personal guide will follow you around. I think they do this also for security reasons. The guide we had did not had much of a clue, but a guide from another group we saw seemed pretty knowledgeable. A lot of the displays are reproductions and only a few are real! However it is still worthwhile to look at everything as also the reproductions are very beautiful and nicely made.I would also not really call it a museum, but more a private samurai entertainment museum. This is because of the limited actual original objects on display. The way the guide goes around and interacts with you. The shows they do and the fact that you can try on some masks to take pictures and the professional photo studio area with different costumes and backdrops and the big shop at the end.Nevertheless a nice little fun place to visit especially, if you are in that area of Tokyo anyway.

Worst guide ever !!. The museum is not impressive but worth a visit. The exhibits include original as well as replicas of Samurai armoury, katana swords and other accessories. It’s rather small and would have been a much nicer experience if there was a proper guide. Before I paid for my ticket I asked the young lady at the ticket booth if they had an “audio guide” – by which I meant a pre-recorded narrative of the museum on headphones. I like this system because they are usually very well made, the content is legitimate, recorded in proper English and you can pace it at your own rhythm. The audio guides at the Edo Museum are very well made. The girl confirmed that they had audio guides so I paid for my ticket. There was no “audio guide” … she was my “audio guide” and began to escort me around the museum. I immediately realised that she was not well informed. I asked her about the katana sword because I had seen a documentary and I knew that the katanas are traditionally made from a specialised Japanese. I could not remember the name of the steel … but she had no clue. Later I looked it up; it’s tamahagane steel. On the second floor I noticed that there were several references to The Siege of Osaka so I was curious and asked her what it was. She didn’t know!! So my recommendation for visitors is that you read about the Samurai before you to the museum so that you can appreciate the experience. My recommendation to the museum: invest in an “audio guide” system with a professional commentary. Alternatively – get qualified guides.

Very cool . My husband and I really enjoyed the museum, we both found it very enjoyable and the staff are awesome! The staff are very knowledgable and the show with the swordsman was very interactive. After the swordsman show hang around as you can dress up and take a photo (for free). The samurai museum is only a short walk from the train station and is located near the robot restaurant.Tip - don't get conned by the people in the streets offering you good drinking deals or good places to go.

Experience the history and passion for the Samurai. We just loved this Museum, the original costumes date back as far as 800 years old, costumes that would otherwise be considered family treasure. The staff are really passionate about the Samurai and all speak quite good English, they're dedicated in explaining the history of the Samurai. We really enjoyed the interactive sword show and dressing up for a photo, I was a blonde Japanese princess :)There's a small entry fee that was well worth the personal tour received. The gift shop had it's own treasures and my favourite souvenir from Japan is a Samurai inspired umbrella that I purchased here.

Intimate, interactive & informative. The Samurai Museum was definitely a highlight for me when visiting Shinjuku. The staff are extremely friendly and can speak English. Staff would go out of their way to explain exhibits to us and even let us try on some of the head gear and hold swords. At the end they let you dress up and take photos as a samurai. They let us tale our own photos as well!I definitely recommend this museum, even though it may appear to be small we spent over an hour there.

Whole lot of fun & super informative !!!. The samurai museum ticked all the right boxes, great way to gain some history and insight into the past lives of Japanese warriors. - easy to find (use Google maps and follow the directions ) look out for the white sign - the displays show information in multiple languages- they allow you to take photos of the displays- you can try on replications which look, weigh and feel like the real thing - if possible, you are assigned a tour guide who goes through each of the periods and displays. They also can answer many questions about the samurais, wars and periods Mostly the staff are super helpful and kind. When they were closing up, one offered to guide us to our next destination in Shinjuku !! Won't forget this experience anytime soon, a MUST for any samurai lover !!!

Pleasantly Surprised . Prior to entering I wasn't expecting much. Then I wasn't that keen on the entry fee. All that went way once inside. We saw the Samurai 'show' on positions/stances. It was atmospheric and at the end very interactive. Had a blast playing with the swords. After that you can take a photo in costume. We also had a very enthusiastic and informative guided tour of the displays. Would definitely recommend you check if out if in Shinjuku.

Interesting and informative. Great little museum, packed with authentic traditional samurai wear. The guide was interesting and provided great information. As a bonus, you get to try on some samurai gear which is pretty fun. It is a small museum so it won't take long to get around.

Worth it . We found the museum hard to find but the displays inside were definitely interesting to see and worth the time we spent. Also gives you a good chance to walk around the Shinjuku area of Tokyo
Was good . Really good museum, a bit small but had lots of information. Gin (or Gim not sure) was packed for of information in fluent English, would definitely recommend it.

Should come if you like samurai or having a long holiday in Tokyo. The ticket was a little expensive. The museum was a little small. But the guide can speak English fluently, introduce very enthusiatically. And the visitor can try the Samurai's clothes.

Fantastic experience. The museum isn't big but they have so much inside, the staff are fantastic, walking you through and describing the details. Samurai show was brilliant and at the end you can have some pics with him.

A great introduction to the life of the samurai. It's a small museum and whilst the exhibits are very well presented they are small in number. What makes the visit worth while is if you visit in the afternoon in time for one of the samurai (Akaido) demonstrations that take place on the hour at 2pm, 3pm and 4pm. Interesting, great fun and inspect some audience participation! The samurai uniforms on display are quite amazing. The shop has a small range and if you want a souvenir to take home such as a replica samurai sword you won't be disappointed. Certainly worth a visit.

Great time with the family!. It is nice place to visit if you are interested about the story of samurai in Japan. Our guide was pretty awesome, he even let all of us try on a real samurai helmet. We had a great time and took lots of pictures as welI. I really recommend you to stay for the show by a professional samurai actor!

Samurai Museum in Shinjuku. Tetsuro (the owner) was very knowledgeable, patient and friendly he gave me a guided tour of the museum. Came in around late evening cost was 1500 Yen. Was awesome to learn and understand further about feudal Japan.
Excellent Museum. Amazing small museum, free demonstration and plenty of English speaking guides for information. Also able to try on a Samurai Helmet

Intresting Museum, But Very Small. The price is a whopping 1,500 yen for a pretty small museum. The exhibits are very intresting, some of the original armor even has bullet holes and cuts from battle. There are a fair amount of reproductions as well though. The guides there were very friendly and informative as well. Overall, intresting to see if you have the money. If you think it is a little too high you are not missing too too much.

Worth a look! . Worth visiting if you have an interest in Samurai warriors. Some great original and re-created armour to look at, along with weapons and a terrific demonstration with samurai swords that really adds to the experience.

Must see. Small but really worth visiting. The best part was the ability to try on some samurai stuff and get some great pictures.
There is also a small but interesting souvenir shop.

Brilliant view of the shogunate. Incredible chance to get a more close up view of the shogunate history. I was lucky enough to take part in the samurai exhibition. As a history teacher I cannot fault the experience, and encourage everyone to go along.

a walkabout in the historic past of the fabled Samurai!. spectacular exhibit of Samurai equipment presented by the owner..he was very informative during the tour and was generous with his time and offered the opportunity to take photos with helmets and swords!

Fun and informative. Lots of fun, we learnt a lot about samurai history, weapons, armour etc, and got to dress up. The staff take you around each display and answer questions very well. Good English too, so it was easy to communicate. Worth a trip

Fun quick visit, get a guided tour. Small collection of original and replica items from samurai times. Geared toward foreign tourists with plenty of English, but you'll enjoy more with a guided tour. You can hear some stories and ask questions. 1500 yen admission. Love hotels right outside if samurai get you that excited..

Very Good. Visited this museum because I had, for years, read about the Samurai and wanted to see what was on display.It is relatively new and it is worth booking a tour - rather than just turning up. If you book, you get a guided tour by a friendly staffer who speaks english and it gives you better insight into the displays.Certainly worth a visit

Good little museum wit cool stuff and you can take pictures. A great place within some cool stuff, and you can dres op and take pictures and a great little souvenir shop, and very helpful staff who tells you what you need to know, cool place

Wonderful and informative museum . We were extremely fortunate to have the owner / curator of the samurai collection show us through the displays. He treated us to a description of the displays, the history of each item and its use.We also got to try on some of the samurai attire and weapons which was brilliant! Highly recommended for a personal and informative tour about the Japanese Samurai history.
Collection and history - guided by a wonderful historian. Passionate staff/owner shared his wonderful insight into the history to accompany the displays. A wonderful collection enjoyed by all
Jake. Displays where very good and staff where extremely friendly and knowledgeable, walked through the exhibit with me giving a guided tour for no extra cost. Worth a visit for sure.

An excellent experience. Small (about 45-90 minutes), you can touch some items. This museum is a great find. The neighborhood of kabuki-cho is fairly touristy and red light, but this is a high quality legitimate museum. It is not gimmicky at all. The collection is small and consists of samurai armor, weapons, and a few murals. Some of the items are authentic historical pieces ranging from 250-800 years old, and some of the items are reproductions or modern restorations. However, these are not low quality reproductions, they are artisan crafted and very well done. I actually enjoyed the reproductions greatly because you can touch, hold, and in some cases even wear the armor. It was a very immersive experience to feel the heft of several of the iron helmets. Our tour guide was the owner of the museum, and he gave a superb tour. He was knowledgeable and interesting, and his English was pretty good. Because we were interested, he got into a lot of the details of the methods of construction and the different styles and types of weapons and armor. Highly recommended.

Very enthusiastic staff and great pieces!. The museum has a great (albeit slightly small) collection and the staff were knowledgable and enthusiastic! After the tour you can dress up in the costume and take photos- well worth it!!

Fun experience . Myself and my wife visited initially out of my interest for samurai swords we ended up staying for the interactive show which was fun and involved learning some samurai sword play .... a lot of armour and swords on display are repudiations still worth a visit alot 1500¥ is quite expensice entry fee

Got to Wear a Mask and hold a sword. The staff were really helpful, telling us about the history and also dressing us up with traditional headdresses and allowing us to hold a Samurai sword.With a live act showing the way of the samurai by sword was a eye opener. Would definitely recommend it to others . A well worth the visit into the old culture .

Awesome history, live sword fighting, very informative guide.. I would recommend this place. The guide was very nice and spoke good English. He took us first to the back room where we were given a fantastic sword fighting demonstration by a Master swordsman. The audience including myself also got to take a sword and be taught a few moves and poses. The tour guide then took us through all the different rooms explaining the swords, armour, history, etc of the Samurai. Very cool!

My day at the museum. Heard about this place through my hotel. Went for a look as i love going to museums. Firstly, the walk down to the museum from the metro station is worth the trip. Shikuju is quirky and cool and entertaining in its own right. The museum was not large but has some really nice period and replica armour on display, along with period firearms and weapons. The owner and staff are what made it extra special though. I was guided through all the displays in person in english, and Provided with a knowledgeable and informative history lesson. There was a sword master demonstration while i was there which you were invited to participate in and you could try on some armour and garb. They also have replica katanas for sale in the gift shop if your country of origin will let you bring it home. All in all a great place to go. Picture taking of the displays is allowed

Samurai-up close!. This small but excellent museum showcases armour, swords and other samurai related items such as bow & arrows. Explanations are in Japanese, English, Korean, etc. Friendly English speaking guides accompanied us throughout the exhibit, answering questions, giving good explanations and encouraging us to take photos and look at the displays up close. Some are reproductions however I've seen originals in the National Museum and those displays were quite uninspiring and sort of well, "dead" These make history come alive. Stays open late and the staff are outstanding-when we asked for a dinner recommendation, our guide insisted on showing us to a nearby place and sure enough, there was a line of locals waiting to eat tasty udon noodles. An excellent experience for anyone interested in history, the military, Samurai or weapons. PS You can dress up in period costume and have your picture taken.

Nice place to buy a replica.. Nice museum worth to see at low cost. You can even wear some of the clothes and take a picture. Unfortunately they're almost all replicas.They do have a shop with some good sword replicas, better prices than in Asakusa alleys.
One of the best places I've ever seen.. For real... You will definitely love this museum if you are into "Sengoku Jidai". Iaido demonstration was also great!

Small, very interesting museum. Deep in history, the tour guide new his stuff. English was pretty good and willing to explain things. Interactive too. You can dress up in the gear and get photos and there are even a short show.

High quality small museum showcasing the Samurai. This is a good place to get a quick understanding of what it was the be a samurai. High quality displays are limited in number as are the English descriptions, so its wise to get a guide. You can be offered to put on the samurai mask and wield the sword for your photo. Worthwhile if you are in the area.

Must see if you are in Shinjuku. Very interesting, original 300-400+ years old armours swords guns etc, you can up dress up and put mask on, photos allowed, everything is translated in english korean etc, nice interior (brand new), enriching stories (private guide included), 1500 per adult, near Shinjuku station, expect 1h15 for the complete tour, gift shop.

Good little tourist spot. Very friendly accommodating staff even though their English wasn't the greatest we got a lot out of the experience. If you go, recommend to in the afternoon so you can watch the samurai demonstration. Some amazing authentic pieces from 100s of years ago.

Worth a visit if you are in the area, but not if you have totravel far or long to reach it.. Fairly small museum. Little info in English so ask for a giude. They are very knowleable and adds value to the experience.

Very interesting little musuem. The Samurai Museum is unusual, being tucked away in Shinjuku among a lot of bars, nightclubs and other more noisy/adult kinds of attractions. The museum and its collection is small, perhaps because it only opened recently, but everything on display is fascinating and beautiful. Well organized displays, informative history, and extremely helpful museum staff made this a great experience. The staff were only too happy to walk with us through the site, answer all our questions, and even let us touch and pick up some of the artifacts!

Super Samurai!. After reading about the museum on Trip Advisor we sought it out in the back streets of Shinjuku. While small, this was a great find with some interesting history about both Japan and the samurai. We had our own personal guide who was informative and entertaining. The demonstration of samurai technique was great and encouraged audience participation which made it more fun. My husband was even allowed to try on a samurai headpiece which was a highlight for him. Would definately recommend a visit.

A Hidden Gem. This was excellent. Everyone received an in depth guided tour. There are outfits that you can touch, and some that you can try on and take your picture with. There are swords you can hold and pose with also. Even if you only have a passing interest in the Samurai - this is a must see. Our tour guide was incredible. He answered all of our questions and make the whole tour extremely interesting. Then when we were done (I was in the last group of the day), our tour guide showed me the way back to the train and showed the other group a great curry restaurant. All of us laughed, learned and had a great time.The gift shop is extremely well priced. Their replica Samurai swords are cheaper than the street shops and are better quality.You could go through the whole exhibit rather quick, but it was much more fun exploring and getting the in depth stories.
Great tourist attraction in Tokyo.. We were very lucky to have the owner guide us around and give us so much information about the displays. We found this to be one of our Tokyo highlights.

Tons of fun, and lots of history!. My friend and I, both 18-year-old girls, came to the Samurai Museum on a whim after our plans for the day had been canceled. It ended up being one of our favorite experiences during our trip!We walked in, and we were greeted by a tour-guide, who to our surprise guided us through the entire museum in English! This was amazing, since my Japanese is very basic, and my friend speaks no Japanese at all, so we were both able to fully enjoy the exhibits and learn all the history behind each one. We spoke with two tour guides (I unfortunately did not get their name, ごめんなさいございます！), and they were extremely friendly and outgoing, and readily spoke to me in both English and Japanese (despite how bad it was)! We also stayed for the short Iaidō performance, which was very cool and worth the watch! Afterwards the martial artist took questions, and was also very energetic and friendly!Overall, this was one of the best experiences of our trip! If you're someone like me who has a passion for Japanese (especially samurai) history, if you enjoy certain pop culture media that references people like Tokugawa Ieyasu (Sengoku Basara, Basilisk) or the Shinsengumi (Gintama, Hakuouki, Peacemaker Kurogane), or if you're like my friend who is just being dragged along, you're sure to have fun!ホントにありがとうございます！楽しかったです！- Olivia (Massachusetts)

A great Tokyo experience. This is THE place to go if you have an interest in Japanese history. Amazing displays of art and armor and weapons. Staff are very friendly and love helping out Foreigners. Go here then grab some Tendon to complete a great experience.
Really intersting!!!. I practiced the katana sword with a katana teacher, had a guided tour of the museum and I could put on a samurai helmet!! (Beware it's quite heavy btw). Great experience!!!

Very interesting but not cheap. Museum includes a guide within the price so value is good but it is not a cheap option.
It is quite a small museum so visit only takes abolut an hour but it is very interesting. My 12 year old son loved it despite the lack of things to touch. It is not really geared to young kids.

Worth your time. I have been to Japan many times however whenever I searched for a Samurai specific museum, I could not find one. All of a sudden this one shows up and I decide to go visit it. The staff is friendly, speak great english and are eager to teach you about the general history and specific armor and weapons they have at the museum. This place opened up just over 4 months ago and it is a personal collection. I would say you can spend a good hour or two here depending how interested you are listening to the guide who will also answer any of your questions. Some of the armor is over 400 years old and weapons 800+ years old. Definitely worth your visit if you are in Tokyo and are interested in the history of Samurai.

Amazing staff . Went to the Samurai Museum at night, it is located near to the shinjuku JR station, about a 10 minute walk for those who are not familiar with the area. Once we entered we were greet with an extremely passionate bunch of staff, as we did not speak Japanese, the staff explained everything to us in English.The whole exhibit takes approximately 30 minutes to 1 hour to complete and entrance tickets for adults are 1,500 yen/pax. I have to highlight that they were very very passionate, and the displays gave me the feel that i was brought back to the edo period, I would give them 6 stars on tripadvisor if I could.

Amazing and interesting. We had a private tour with a man that worked there named Ging. Offered us information for over an hour and told us all about the suits and armour and swords. He made it even more worthwhile, especially as we love Samurai history. Thank you Ging you are a very nice man and the museum was excellent.

Takes you back in time.. I enjoyed my visit to this museum and thank Tripadvisor for the reviews. It is a nice place to learn while seeing samurai armor and weapons. They even allow you to touch the armor and hold the sword. Replica swords are also sold. A family photo wearing armor for boys and kimono for girls is a nice souvenir (500 Yen only ). The entrance fee of 1,200 Yen is also reasonable. Highly recommended if you are in Tokyo with boys in the family.

Great history great staff. Great little museum learnt a lot of history, be sure to stick around for the samurai show upstairs (remove your shoes) "I saw people who didn't" show was quite interesting and answered everyone's questions very well, the owner gave my friend and I a private tour and told us all the history of his collection piece by piece, Really great guy and all other staff were very respectful and always smiling which I was happy to see,

Interesting, reasonable value, but one hour is plenty of time. Interesting, reasonable value, but one hour is plenty of time. Some of the suits are really interesting, and it is worth a visit but don't lock it in as a major event.

Personal tour, small but interesting. Really enjoyed this. It is a relatively small collection but long enough to enjoy an hour or more here. Great for kids. I have a 16 and 14 year old and they really enjoyed the personalised tour we were given and trying on some samurai armour at the end. Run by an absolutely charming Japanese man.

Samurai museum step into Japan culture! . Went with 8 friends so a very large group to cater for in most of these places in Tokyo (most of the buildings being small) First thing was that it was kind of difficult to find, it's in the middle of an alleyway off the Main Street 3 or 4 blocks away from the closet train centre BUT! It would have been easier to find if we had thought to write down directions before we left as we haven't bought any SIM cards. The price was ¥1500 which I consider very well priced for the service provided. The first 30 or so minutes was spent walking around the rooms of the two story museum with a guide (all of the staff members spoke very very good English!) telling us seriously fascinating information about Japanese history and culture. During the guided tour, one person from our group was able to put on a helmet and mask and take photos (seriously amazing experience) Then we were able to watch a lovely demonstration of a samurai who had been training for 10 years, model a fight with a sword. After the display (about 5 minutes) he invited people from the crowd (which was only our group of 9 and one other couple) up to go through the movements with him. Very funny and entertaining. There was then a questions section where we would ask questions then they would ask us questions about the differences in our culture ect (very engaging and fun!) Then the souvenir shop where the prices were great! Full replica samurai swords from ¥7000-19000 and detailed models for about ¥2500.All in all a great experience for traditional Japanese culture, very interesting and enjoyable and most importantly affordable!!

Amazing Museum To Visit. An amazing museum to learn about samurai. The display was well presented with English translation. The staff able to converse in English. So we are able to converse with them. We got a private tour and the staff explain each and every exhibit. We meet the owner of the museum who also came and give some explanation of some of the exhibit. You would get to see samurai armour and weapon. There are also costumes, replica armour and weapon that you can dress up and take photos. But do go during the day as there are lots of "adult" entertainment shops in that area.
Fascinating . Small museum but definitely not run of the mill. Very interesting and kept the hubby on a high for a few hours!

Ok. But the area around it looks dodgy. . This place was actually quite good. Some authentic old samurai armour, weapons & paraphernalia, and some replica armour as well nice sword demonstration.
