Friendly staff. And the obligatory gift shop. Worth the visit but come during the day & don't leave too late, especially with young kids. The area is full of "adult" type shops & entertainment.

Amazing museum. We arrived and there was no one else in the museum. We were given a private tour and learnt all about the history of the Sumari and the costume.learnt about the different weapons and how Japan became westernize. We were there for about 1.5 hrs. Our 4 yr asked so many questions and was fasinated by it all. We got to dress up and take as mant photos as we liked. This truly a mustin Shinjuku and so easy to find

Interesting displays but a bit small . The displays was well presented with English translations and the staff provided a free tour. There was a free show involving a gentlemen pretending to be a samurai and answering questions. There was a chance to hold a sword and try on armour for an additional ¥500. However it was a fair bit smaller than expected and wouldn't take more that about 45 minutes to see everything.

Great for a short visit on a cold night. We arrived at the museum to find it nearly empty, and the owner/manager started offering us a private tour. After a few others arrived, he offered to let us see a show even though one was not scheduled for this time. The show itself was short, and although not exhilarating by any means, it was interesting. There are a few interesting things to look at as well, and you are encouraged to touch the samurai armour and take photos. We spent maybe an hour here total and this was definitely enough to take in all the museum had to offer.

Great cultural experience!. Awesome samurai performance. Everyone spoke good english. After the show there was a tour and we got to meet the owner and he explained samurai culture and history in great detail. Will recomend to everyone, will be back before i go to buy a sword.

A must see for the history buff!. We were in Shinjuko on business but had one day to relax and decided to see if there was anything within walking distance that was worth a visit. My husband is a huge history buff and absolutely loved the one on one attention they gave us explaining each and every piece and answering all of our questions. Very intimate atmosphere with an extremely dedicated staff. Highly recommend to anyone wanting to learn the Samurai history.

Great Samurai History. Visited this Museum as it is located just behind the Hotel Gracery Godzilla! Staff are friendly and helpful. The owner leads the tour and explains the history of the Samurai and Japan. Speaks good English. This was a welcome break from a vacation trip that everyone should experience. Authentic and very old Samurai exhibits, very impressive. One will come away from this museum googling and reading up on the Samurai!
“Must see ”. It has two floors and can't be a bit hard to find but if you give the address to a taxi your good.. On the whole a nice break from all the shopping .

Great place to visit. Only small however very interesting.Staff were great and super friendly.Some of the items date back to over 700 years ago.They even have a Samurai dress up area so you can get a genuine photo with Samurai Helmut,sword etc.Really recommend and it's just down the street from the Gracery Hotel.

Authentic Samurai Museum. This is difficult to find if you just have a map. You need to follow the english landmarks unless you can read Japanese.Amazing experience. Worth a trip to Shinjuku just to see some of the authentic samurai gear and highly crafted replicas as well as Samurai swords dating back up to 800 years old. Cool place, museum is set up like a dojo, plenty to see worth the 1500 yen. A nice topper to my Tokyo weekend. Also can dress up as a samurai and don an expensive samurai helmet replica and katana for a nice selfie souvineir.
Great Mesuem. Great Museum! Staff spoke great English and was extra friendly, making sure we learned some history during our visit!

Hidden gem in Kabukicho. Not easy to find but once you do, you won't regret it. Small but it has a good selection. And make sure you watch the show as well. Try on the clothes and practice with the master

Nice little museum.. Nestled in the heart of Shinjuku, a nice cosy museum to visit. Very dedicate staff who really made you feel welcome . The onsite samurai katana display was impressive. On the whole a nice break from all the shopping .

Must see . I loved this museum. It has two floors and can't be a bit hard to find but if you give the address to a taxi your good. It shows you the info in english and they have so many great facts. The staff is tremendous and they give you a tour and break everything down to you. You have to visit this museum. This really was the one museum I was looking forward too.

Cultural. I recommend stopping by this place on your first day in Tokyo. Collection overall was fair , there were some good vibes in a few of the rooms. The helmets were nice , and souvenir wise - you can pick up a few things for a relatively fair price . The best part for the oldies is definitely the photo op with your choice of a few ensembles at the end. PS > The team is excellent !

Great Visit. We visited this museum since we wanted to learn basic facts about the Samurai warriors and culture. The museum is new and has signs in English. What we loved the most was the hospitality of the owner, as well as his enthusiasm. We dressed up as Samurai and had free pictures taken. Great visit. Would definitely recommend.

The best choice of my trip!!. This is a totally unexpected experience that I found such a great place to visit. Though it's located in the alley, its display and guidance was absolutely worth the time. The museum curator explained the history thoroughly and has been very patient to answer all the questions. I strongly recommend this museum to anyone who wants to visit Tokyo. You will not regret it!!

Very Interesting!. I had some time available last week while in Japan and decided to visit the Samurai Museum, which was close to my hotel in Shinjuku. What a wonderful find!I thoroughly enjoyed the info provided by the curator, who was clearly passionate about its history and provided as much or as little as one desired. As a history buff, I learned so much. As noted, it isn't very large, but it was well worth the time and I highly recommend it.

Interesting and enjoyable . We found this little museum so interesting and really enjoyed it's peaceful atmosphere and friendly staff. We even got to play dress ups with some of the samurai helmets and other traditional clothing - loved it! Would definitely recommend a visit.
Small but amazing! . Costs 1500¥ to get in but the collection is pretty good. A lot of original pieces and a few copies that they let you touch and wear.
Must Visit!!! . Fun and very educational! Guide is very friendly and kind. Very interactive-- we had the chance to wear the samurai helmet. Once in a lifetime experience. Awesome museum! :)

Samurai wow... what an amazing find!. This museum is put together by a curator who is the collector, and guide. The details, and care to explain made this experience amazing. To see 400+ year old, authentic Samuari items is a special treat. To have the collector wxplain any question, is like a personal tour. This is one stop you must make when in Tokyo, it is well worth it.

Fun & Interesting. My group ended up here because we received a discount coupon at our hotel (¥1300 as opposed to ¥1500). We were so glad that we did! There's a good mix of authentic and replica armor. A decent collection of swords and guns for such a small museum. Beautiful lighting for the displays. The staff is helpful and fun. At the end of the tour they provided many fun photo opportunities.

Must visit. Period.. You will be distracted by all the bright lights in shinjuku, but ignore the noise and come here. It's unassuming but once you come inside you'll be treated like royalty with personal assistance and tour. The place provides an excellent assortment of genuine samurai gear AND you will have some sweet photo opportunities.

Unmissable – Awesome visit. Visita Impresionante e Imprescindible!!!Queríamos complementar nuestro viaje a Tokio con la visita a este museo donde poder ver armaduras, vestidos y espadas tradicionales japonesas, todo un viaje en el tiempo.Fue fácil de encontrar y el personal increíblemente amable, atento y servicial, incluso el dueño Sr. Tetsuro-san nos guio por su museo dándonos muy interesantes explicaciones de las piezas expuestas así como de la historia de Japón. Como gran colofón final, se pueden hacer fotos vestidos con réplicas de armaduras y espadas!!! Qué bonito recuerdo tenemos!!! No dejen de visitar este museo, merece mucho la pena!!! Una de las mejores experiencias en nuestro viaje a Japon.Unmissable – Awesome visitWe wanted to finish our trip to Tokyo with a visit to this museum where we could see traditional Japanese armors, suits and swords… a trip to the past.It was easy to find and the personnel was extraordinarily kind and helpful, even the owner, Mr. Tetsuro-san who kindly guided us through his museum, giving us very interesting insight in the story behind the different pieces in the museum as well as Japan’s history and life.The cherry on the top… you can have your picture taken wearing the samurai armor, sword, etc.. What a sweet memories!!Do not miss to visit this museum, it worth it!!! It was one of the best memories of our trip to Japan.

Fun and interesting experience . My family of 3 children from 9 to 16 thoroughly enjoyed ourselves in this little museum which is so nondescript on the exterior. The staff are attentive and even though they may not speak very fluent English, they try their very best to explain.

Delightful Experience. The Samurai Museum is quite small, their a few displays which would be disappointing to most, but what makes the experience is the passion of the museum curator. You can really tell he loves his work, he gave us a personal tour through the museum, explaining the history behind each piece. He is very knowledgeable and answered every question.

Enjoyable Samurai Museum. Visited Samurai Museum with my Junior and young boys. We were amazed at the beautiful displays. Glad to have the owner/curator who walked through with us and explained the history. He is very knowledgeable and appreciated his patience & attention given to my boy's queries. Do not miss the chance to play dress up on the 2nd floor. We had a great time here and my boys loved it a lot!

An enjoyable, peaceful tour of beautiful Samurai artifacts. This was an amazing discovery right in the Shinjuku area - I was so glad to find it! Everything in the museum is beautifully presented, with evident love and respect. I went early in the day, and was fortunate enough to have the owner/curator personally walk me through the museum. He spoke good English and generously took the time to answer my questions and explain the items, their history and significance to me as we moved through the exhibits. Unlike the city museums, you have plenty of time and space to examine this amazing Samurai exhibit and take photos in a nice, quiet setting which I really appreciated. On the way out, the small gift shop also has some nice items to pick up as souvenirs and help further support the museum. I really enjoyed my visit to the Samurai Museum and would highly recommend it to anyone with an interest in Samurai-era artifacts, especially if you would enjoy seeing these items in a peaceful setting without being rushed through by crowds like at the noisy big museums. Very interesting and enjoyable!

Delightful little museum, worth a look. Thankfully we'd looked up things to do in the area because I doubt we'd have found this little gem just by wandering around. It's down a little side street in Shinjuku prefecture close to our hotel (Citadines Central) and could so easily be missed. In fact we walked past it twice before we realised it was what we were looking for.Not huge but very well done with good explanations of each exhibit. This place is great for a little cultural history, and the owners are more than pleased to walk with you and explain if you have questions. They are clearly very proud of their museum and with good reason, it's small but informative, and you'll even get the chance to play dress up and have your pic taken if you're of a mind to do so. It doesn't seem to get very busy - we were the only visitors at the time but I preferred the lack of crowds if I'm honest.Entry fee wasn't expensive, and there's a little gift area at the end. You'll need a couple hours max if you like to read everything.

Great Museum. We visited this museum a few days ago. We couldn't find the museum and a person on the street came to our aid and called them directly. To our astonishment they sent a staff member to guide us to the museum. The customer service was exceptional from start to finish. We received a guided tour of the museum and it was very informative and entertaining. It was one of the highlights of our trip.

Provides a great insight into the Samurai aspect of Japanese culture and history. All the displays are beautiful and instructive, the museum reveals the Japanese soul and it removed all my notions about the Samurai, especially the notions acquired in movies!!!

Amazing museum. Excellent little museum. Loved the simple layout and effective lighting that showed the display pieces really well. The staff were very knowledgable about the exhibits and were great at giving additional bits of information. It's great to see such a museum in Japan as there really aren't many that are dedicated to this interesting period in the countries history

Amazing. Do not hesitate to visit this place if 1) you are interested in Samurai 2) you do not feel like spending half a day in a museum with large amounts of other tourists 3) want to support the local and very knowledgeable owner who personally provides you with a tour. The place does not really fit into the area but that only made it more charming for us

So much passion.. You have heard of afficiandio, you know conngduur, you have to experience this passion. I knew very little about the subject matter going in, maybe watched The Last Samuri years ago. I knew it was fiction, this place set me straight.
Lovely Staff!. Really cool little museum. There was a nice lady who showed us around and she even let us take photos with the samurai gear for free (there was a sign that read 1 photo = ¥500)!

A must see for anyone who likes swords and samurais. A great collection of armors, swords and artifacts. The hosts are even better, they're very friendly and let us do cosplay with armor and replica katanas.

Must see if you are interested in Samurai History. The owners are great and friendly. They will try their best to explain their exhibits. very nice showcase and display in small tatami rooms. picture taking is allowed and entrance fee for adults is 1500 yen.

Best Museum in Tokyo . This museum was great from the very beginning. The staff was super friendly and the very well informed manager took me around the whole museum like it was a personal tour. He was soo knowledgable and answered all the questions I had about samurai. The displays are outstanding as well with well preserved relics from samurai past all looking marvelous under perfectly dimmed lights. There is also the chance to touch actual samurai masks and helmets which was simply amazing. Los of photo oops including a chance to take your photo wearing traditional samurai outfit. Don't miss this great place.

Awesome . The staff is super nice and helpful. Almost personalized guidance.It's small but you can see some really nice replicas and also original material from hundreds of years ago. 100% recommended!

Superb and beautiful boutique museum. My teenage son and I visited with only two other people in the museum, so it was just like a private viewing. The staff are super friendly and the owner is very passionate about his collection. He gave us a guided tour and even let my son try on a helmet from the exhibition. A beautiful gem of a museum, small enough to do in an hour and a half but impressive enough to give you an insight into samurai armour, weapons and lifestyle. This had to be one of my favourite places in Tokyo to visit. A must see!

Small and compact with intriguing exhibits. I had this small museum to myself the day I visited and enjoyed the great variety of samurai armour and weaponry. Most of the exhibits are replicas, naturally enough, but they are beautifully executed. The staff were very friendly and helpful, and the owner spoke good English. The perfect place to spend half an hour or so getting to know a fascinating aspect of Japanese history.

Best thing to see in Tokyo! . I went here not knowing what to expect. It was really interesting! The owner was very nice and showed me the exhibits. This museum is two levels. I think the upstairs was added recently! The old gun collection is pretty incredible. Front of musuem is easily marked. There are some brief English translations on plaques. I wish there were dates on them as everything is pretty impressive! However the staff can tell you...

Small but perfectly formed!. Desperately attempting to do some educational stuff with my 14 year old manga and gaming son, I saw the reviews for this place. He wasn't that keen but as soon as we got inside that changed. The atmosphere is really peaceful and the use of Incense transports you immediately. The samurai armour on display are a combination of authentic (hundreds of years old) and (amazing) replicas. The arms and swords are real works of art, even though I don't like weapons I could admire the craftsmanship. We had fun at the end trying on costumes and taking photos, it's only small so you have done the round fairly quickly but well worth a visit.

A boutique museum with style - make sure you see this!. Authentic samurai armour and weapons in a boutique museum that has been beautifully designed and presented. We spent a really enjoyable hour or so looking through the exhibits covering the samurai era of Japanese history, each displayed in a series of rooms lined with tatami mats, tastefully lit and with soothing music to set the scene. The museum owner gave us a guided tour and was only too happy to answer our questions and provide more insight into the time of the samurai. The staff were also delightful and helped make this a fun experience. This place oozes style.

Exactly how you would want it to be....... Authentic with really nice decor, ambiance and layout. The owner is very passionate on the subject and has amassed a great collection over twenty years. The other staff are lovely and i hope this does very well as it is new!

Like visiting your own private collection. This is a well set up small look at one mans private collection. It is very well displayed and we were lucky enough that the owner was there to answer our enquiries and effective give us a private tour and history guide to Samurai.Our party included 2 young adults who found the displays very engaging. It ends with a photo opportunity to dress in Samurai gear. A great 1 hour visit close to Snihjuku station near the robot cafe.

Highly recommended: Little cultural gem contrasting livley Shinjuku. This small museum has been opened just a few weeks ago, and serves as a wonderful cultural contrast to lively Shinjuku area. It displays several very well-preserved samurai armor suits, as well as weapons and swords, and provides a bit of background on the history of japanese Samurai. It covers two floors of a historical building in Shinjuku, and is perfect, if you would like to spend about an hour with a cultural heritage of Japan. In case, you are interested in more background information, the owner and the staff would be glad to provide it, even if the communication is sometimes a bit difficult, but you can always feel the dedication of the owner and staff to provide a wonderful experience to their guests. You can also make pictures of your own, dressed in a historic samurai armor including helmet and sword, which is a fun experience. We can highly recommend this small hidden gem, and hope, that many travellers would visit it, when they are in Shinjuku. It is only 2 blocks north from the Robot Restaurant, or 2 blocks north-east from the hotel complex "Gracery Shinjuku" (with the Godzilla on its roof).

Just perfect. I went there to experience some Japanese cultural history and was not disappointed. As I went early, I was alone in the museum and got the fantastic owner as a personal guide. You can tell he's very proud of the museum and it's artifacts, he even took out a few for me to hold. The museums interior is very traditional and old fashioned, with a light touch of incense (that you can buy in the shop) and relaxing music. I felt very centered, happy and calm after leaving the museum, it was a well needed pause from the otherwise high pace of Tokyo. Fun parts was the masks, outfits and swords you can try on and get photographed with, probably the coolest selfie you'll get in Tokyo. And of course - you'll even learn a bit of Japanese history!

Wauw - Great museum!. We had the greatest experience at the Samurai Museum today. Friendly staff telling about the samurai eras and how to wear the helmets and armour - and we were even allowed to hold weapons and try on the clothing. Very interesting place. Highly recommended. Small place with lots of atmosphere! Thank you!

Great new museum!. We discovered the Samurai Museum by chance because it was near our hotel and it was an amazing experience. Situated in Kabuchiko, in the heart of Shinjuku. Great piece of Japanese history.

HIGHLY RECOMMENDED!. The best place if you love Samurais!!! You can try a samurai armour and take pictures of everything. Really nice place with real armours! Its located in Shinjuku right behind the Godzilla statue.

Authentic and Interesting Change of pace. Spread over 2 floors with lots of interesting artefacts the museum is a good break from the hustle and bustle of Shinjuku. Not far from the Robot Restaurant, I found this unexpected jewel. My understanding is that this was originally a private collection that has been open to the public. It was interesting to see the changes in armour and the swords over the ages, and the care and presentation is fantastic. They were offering free photos of you dressed up with some samurai outfits/ swords - taken by your friends or their staff would manage your phone/camera - good for Facebook profile pics etc.It was also a good place to buy good reproduction samurai swords (if that is your thing) from fairly cheap (under US$100 to more expensive). I always wanted one as a teenager when i was into karate. They also talk a bit about when samurai moved to using guns and have some original guns on display too (you cannot buy any guns). It is a loss to move from honour and mastery of a sword to shooting people from a distance. I also like samurai movies so i could be biased. You can also buy a small model samurai armour at the museum - which is a great idea for teenage and older gifts especially for boys. In Japan a Japanese Doll or Kimono is a good gift for a woman, and an equivalent but cool gift for a boy would be the small samurai armour (and not as pointy as a sword). If i can get pictures from my phone i will attach.Staff were helpful and enthusiastic about their collection, and I would recommend a visit. Note - you take your shoes off on the second floor - so wear nice socks...

Interesting and comprehensive museum.. Although this museum is fairly small, it offers a great selection of items ranging from early muromachi period to late edo/early meiji period. The staff is pretty knowledgable and also speak english fairly well.

An unexpected. A very enjoyable experience. The photos on the wall outside didn't do the place justice - making it look like a very small in-and-out type place, but it wasn't. It was the perfect size, not too short that you felt it was a waste of money, and not too long that it got boring.The staff were extremely pleasant and fun--one could see they wanted visitors to have the best experience rather than the typical snooty museum. Everything came across as very honest, even the beautiful swords that one could purchase at the end were such good value I had to double check I was converting the currency right.

A hidden jewel of a museum in Shinjuku. Looking like lost tourists studying a map on the street, we were approached by a kind gentleman who spoke excellent English.As it happens, Mr. Tetsuro Koyano had just opened the Samurai Museum one week prior & invited us attend his museum as guests. I have long had a great interest in the shogun eras, especially in yabusame, but artifacts from that time in most museums I’ve been to have been sporadic. The Samurai Museum is replete with armory, weaponry, historical information, and the like. The collection is spread over two floors &, while I imagine additional artifacts will be added over time, it has been excellently curated. I cannot stress how fulfilling visiting this museum was for us. We literally spent our last couple of hours of our stay in Japan at the museum, then headed straight to the airport for our return journey.

Interesting new samurai museum. Happened to walk past and discover this new place. Small museum that does not take a lot of time to see. Beautiful sets of armor and other interesting items. Surprising change of pace from surrounding neighborhood activities.

The middle of the journey, it is recommended place to stop by!. To be meet in this museum at Shinjuku Kabukicho, I was impressed to unexpected encounter. Cool in the quaint appearance, stunning armor form a line and Once inside, spreads suddenly space, such as time slip. In 2F, and then view it take off your shoes. I feel stylish good offices incorporating casually Japanese lifestyle. You can see the familiar and great swords and helmet. Also the history of Japan through the "Samurai" was also able to learn interesting. There was also a space that can photographed wearing armor and helmet.
